âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
éœ€è¦æ— ä»£ç†æ–¹å¼æ”¶é›†VMwareç¯å¢ƒæ•°æ®ï¼Œç”Ÿæˆç½‘ç»œä¾èµ–å…³ç³»å›¾è¡¨ï¼Œæ”¯æŒå¯¼å‡ºå¯è§†åŒ–æ ¼å¼
Question #424
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company runs a software-as-a-service (SaaS) application on AWS. The application consists of AWS Lambda functions and an Amazon RDS for MySQL Multi-AZ database. During market events, the application has a much higher workload than normal. Users notice slow response times during the peak periods because of many database connections. The company needs to improve the scalable performance and availability of the database. Which solution meets these requirements?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: LambdaRDSCloudWatchRoute53
Knowledge Areas: æ•°æ®åº“æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§
Scenarios: è‡ªåŠ¨æ‰©å±•æ€§èƒ½è°ƒä¼˜
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥æ± Aurora ReplicaRDS Proxyè¯»å†™åˆ†ç¦»
A.
Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm action that triggers a Lambda function to add an Amazon RDS for MySQL read replica when resource utilization hits a threshold.
B.
Migrate the database to Amazon Aurora, and add a read replica. Add a database connection pool outside of the Lambda handler function.
C.
Migrate the database to Amazon Aurora, and add a read replica. Use Amazon Route 53 weighted records.
D.
Migrate the database to Amazon Aurora, and add an Aurora Replica. Configure Amazon RDS Proxy to manage database connection pools.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨AWSä¸Šè¿è¡Œè½¯ä»¶å³æœåŠ¡(SaaS)åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚è¯¥åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºç”±AWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°å’ŒAmazon RDS for MySQL Multi-AZæ•°æ®åº“ç»„æˆã€‚åœ¨å¸‚åœºäº‹ä»¶æœŸé—´ï¼Œåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºçš„å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½æ¯”æ­£å¸¸æƒ…å†µé«˜å¾—å¤šã€‚ç”¨æˆ·æ³¨æ„åˆ°åœ¨é«˜å³°æœŸç”±äºå¤§é‡æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥å¯¼è‡´å“åº”æ—¶é—´ç¼“æ…¢ã€‚å…¬å¸éœ€è¦æé«˜æ•°æ®åº“çš„å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§èƒ½å’Œå¯ç”¨æ€§ã€‚å“ªä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºCloudWatchå‘Šè­¦åŠ¨ä½œï¼Œå½“èµ„æºåˆ©ç”¨ç‡è¾¾åˆ°é˜ˆå€¼æ—¶è§¦å‘Lambdaå‡½æ•°æ·»åŠ RDS MySQLåªè¯»å‰¯æœ¬ B. å°†æ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»åˆ°Auroraï¼Œæ·»åŠ åªè¯»å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œåœ¨Lambdaå¤„ç†å‡½æ•°å¤–æ·»åŠ æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥æ±  C. å°†æ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»åˆ°Auroraï¼Œæ·»åŠ åªè¯»å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Route 53åŠ æƒè®°å½• D. å°†æ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»åˆ°Auroraï¼Œæ·»åŠ Aurora Replicaï¼Œé…ç½®RDS Proxyç®¡ç†æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥æ± 
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³Lambdaåº”ç”¨åœ¨é«˜å³°æœŸå› æ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥è¿‡å¤šå¯¼è‡´çš„æ€§èƒ½é—®é¢˜
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aé€‰é¡¹åŠ¨æ€æ·»åŠ å‰¯æœ¬å¤æ‚ä¸”å»¶è¿Ÿé«˜ï¼›Bé€‰é¡¹åœ¨Lambdaå¤–ç®¡ç†è¿æ¥æ± ä¸ç°å®ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹Route53ä¸é€‚ç”¨äºæ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥ç®¡ç†
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
éœ€è¦åŒæ—¶è§£å†³æ•°æ®åº“æ€§èƒ½æ‰©å±•å’Œè¿æ¥æ± ç®¡ç†ä¸¤ä¸ªæ ¸å¿ƒé—®é¢˜
Question #425
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company is planning to migrate an application from on premises to the AWS Cloud. The company will begin the migration by moving the application's underlying data storage to AWS. The application data is stored on a shared file system on premises, and the application servers connect to the shared file system through SMB. A solutions architect must implement a solution that uses an Amazon S3 bucket for shared storage. Until the application is fully migrated and code is rewritten to use native Amazon S3 APIs, the application must continue to have access to the data through SMB. The solutions architect must migrate the application data to AWS to its new location while still allowing the on-premises application to access the data. Which solution will meet these requirements?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: S3FSxSystems-ManagerEC2
Knowledge Areas: å­˜å‚¨ç®¡ç†æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘
Scenarios: è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘æ··åˆäº‘æ¶æ„
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æ–‡ä»¶ç½‘å…³SMBåè®®æ··åˆå­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®è¿ç§»
A.
Create a new Amazon FSx for Windows File Server file system. Configure AWS DataSync with one location for the on-premises file share and one location for the new Amazon FSx file system. Create a new DataSync task to copy the data from the on-premises file share location to the Amazon FSx file system.
B.
Create an S3 bucket for the application. Copy the data from the on-premises storage to the S3 bucket.
C.
Deploy an AWS Server Migration Service (AWS SMS) VM to the on-premises environment. Use AWS SMS to migrate the file storage server from on premises to an Amazon EC2 instance.
D.
Create an S3 bucket for the application. Deploy a new AWS Storage Gateway file gateway on an on-premises VM. Create a new file share that stores data in the S3 bucket and is associated with the file gateway. Copy the data from the on-premises storage to the new file gateway endpoint.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸è®¡åˆ’å°†åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä»æœ¬åœ°è¿ç§»åˆ°AWSäº‘ã€‚å…¬å¸å°†é¦–å…ˆè¿ç§»åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºçš„åº•å±‚æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åˆ°AWSã€‚åº”ç”¨æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨æœ¬åœ°å…±äº«æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿä¸Šï¼Œåº”ç”¨æœåŠ¡å™¨é€šè¿‡SMBè¿æ¥åˆ°å…±äº«æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå¿…é¡»å®ç°ä¸€ä¸ªä½¿ç”¨Amazon S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶è¿›è¡Œå…±äº«å­˜å‚¨çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚åœ¨åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå®Œå…¨è¿ç§»å¹¶é‡å†™ä»£ç ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨åŸç”ŸAmazon S3 APIä¹‹å‰ï¼Œåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¿…é¡»ç»§ç»­é€šè¿‡SMBè®¿é—®æ•°æ®ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå¿…é¡»å°†åº”ç”¨æ•°æ®è¿ç§»åˆ°AWSçš„æ–°ä½ç½®ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ä»å…è®¸æœ¬åœ°åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè®¿é—®æ•°æ®ã€‚
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºæ–°çš„Amazon FSx for Windows File Serveræ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œé…ç½®AWS DataSyncè¿›è¡Œæ•°æ®å¤åˆ¶ B. åˆ›å»ºS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ï¼Œç›´æ¥å¤åˆ¶æœ¬åœ°å­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®åˆ°S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ C. éƒ¨ç½²AWS SMS VMåˆ°æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒï¼Œä½¿ç”¨SMSè¿ç§»æ–‡ä»¶å­˜å‚¨æœåŠ¡å™¨åˆ°EC2å®ä¾‹ D. åˆ›å»ºS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ï¼Œéƒ¨ç½²AWS Storage Gatewayæ–‡ä»¶ç½‘å…³ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå…³è”åˆ°æ–‡ä»¶ç½‘å…³çš„æ–°æ–‡ä»¶å…±äº«
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
åœ¨ä¿æŒSMBè®¿é—®çš„åŒæ—¶å°†æœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶å­˜å‚¨è¿ç§»åˆ°S3
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aä½¿ç”¨FSxè€ŒéS3ä½œä¸ºæœ€ç»ˆå­˜å‚¨ï¼›Bç¼ºå°‘SMBè®¿é—®èƒ½åŠ›ï¼›Cä½¿ç”¨SMSè¿ç§»æ•´ä¸ªæœåŠ¡å™¨è€Œéä¸“æ³¨å­˜å‚¨è¿ç§»
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
éœ€è¦åŒæ—¶æ»¡è¶³S3ä½œä¸ºæœ€ç»ˆå­˜å‚¨ç›®æ ‡å’Œä¿æŒSMBåè®®è®¿é—®çš„åŒé‡è¦æ±‚
Question #426
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A global company has a mobile app that displays ticket barcodes. Customers use the tickets on the mobile app to attend live events. Event scanners read the ticket barcodes and call a backend API to validate the barcode data against data in a database. After the barcode is scanned, the backend logic writes to the database's single table to mark the barcode as used. The company needs to deploy the app on AWS with a DNS name of api.example.com. The company will host the database in three AWS Regions around the world. Which solution will meet these requirements with the LOWEST latency?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: DynamoDBLambdaECSEKSCloudFrontRoute53+1 more
Knowledge Areas: æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡æ•°æ®åº“
Scenarios: è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: å…¨çƒåˆ†å¸ƒå¼æ¶æ„è¾¹ç¼˜è®¡ç®—æ•°æ®åº“å…¨çƒå¤åˆ¶æœ€ä½å»¶è¿Ÿä¼˜åŒ–
A.
Host the database on Amazon Aurora global database clusters. Host the backend on three Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) clusters that are in the same Regions as the database. Create an accelerator in AWS Global Accelerator to route requests to the nearest ECS cluster. Create an Amazon Route 53 record that maps api.example.com to the accelerator endpoint.
B.
Host the database on Amazon Aurora global database clusters. Host the backend on three Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) clusters that are in the same Regions as the database. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution with the three clusters as origins. Route requests to the nearest EKS cluster. Create an Amazon Route 53 record that maps api.example.com to the CloudFront distribution.
C.
Host the database on Amazon DynamoDB global tables. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Associate the CloudFront distribution with a CloudFront function that contains the backend logic to validate the barcodes. Create an Amazon Route 53 record that maps api.example.com to the CloudFront distribution.
D.
Host the database on Amazon DynamoDB global tables. Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution. Associate the CloudFront distribution with a Lambda@Edge function that contains the backend logic to validate the barcodes. Create an Amazon Route 53 record that maps api.example.com to the CloudFront distribution.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¨çƒå…¬å¸æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¾ç¤ºç¥¨åˆ¸æ¡å½¢ç çš„ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨ã€‚å®¢æˆ·ä½¿ç”¨ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨ä¸­çš„ç¥¨åˆ¸å‚åŠ ç°åœºæ´»åŠ¨ã€‚æ´»åŠ¨æ‰«æå™¨è¯»å–ç¥¨åˆ¸æ¡å½¢ç å¹¶è°ƒç”¨åç«¯APIæ¥éªŒè¯æ¡å½¢ç æ•°æ®ä¸æ•°æ®åº“ä¸­çš„æ•°æ®ã€‚æ‰«ææ¡å½¢ç åï¼Œåç«¯é€»è¾‘å†™å…¥æ•°æ®åº“çš„å•ä¸ªè¡¨ä»¥æ ‡è®°æ¡å½¢ç ä¸ºå·²ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚å…¬å¸éœ€è¦åœ¨AWSä¸Šéƒ¨ç½²åº”ç”¨ï¼ŒDNSåç§°ä¸ºapi.example.comã€‚å…¬å¸å°†åœ¨å…¨çƒä¸‰ä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸæ‰˜ç®¡æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚å“ªç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€ä½å»¶è¿Ÿæ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœ¨Amazon Aurora global database clustersä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚åœ¨ä¸æ•°æ®åº“ç›¸åŒåŒºåŸŸçš„ä¸‰ä¸ªAmazon ECSé›†ç¾¤ä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡åç«¯ã€‚åœ¨AWS Global Acceleratorä¸­åˆ›å»ºåŠ é€Ÿå™¨å°†è¯·æ±‚è·¯ç”±åˆ°æœ€è¿‘çš„ECSé›†ç¾¤ã€‚åˆ›å»ºRoute 53è®°å½•å°†api.example.comæ˜ å°„åˆ°åŠ é€Ÿå™¨ç«¯ç‚¹ã€‚ B. åœ¨Amazon Aurora global database clustersä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚åœ¨ä¸æ•°æ®åº“ç›¸åŒåŒºåŸŸçš„ä¸‰ä¸ªAmazon EKSé›†ç¾¤ä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡åç«¯ã€‚åˆ›å»ºCloudFrontåˆ†å‘ï¼Œä»¥ä¸‰ä¸ªé›†ç¾¤ä¸ºæºç«™ã€‚å°†è¯·æ±‚è·¯ç”±åˆ°æœ€è¿‘çš„EKSé›†ç¾¤ã€‚åˆ›å»ºRoute 53è®°å½•æ˜ å°„åˆ°CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚ C. åœ¨Amazon DynamoDB global tablesä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚åˆ›å»ºCloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚å°†CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ä¸åŒ…å«éªŒè¯æ¡å½¢ç åç«¯é€»è¾‘çš„CloudFront functionå…³è”ã€‚åˆ›å»ºRoute 53è®°å½•æ˜ å°„åˆ°CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚ D. åœ¨Amazon DynamoDB global tablesä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚åˆ›å»ºCloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚å°†CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ä¸åŒ…å«éªŒè¯æ¡å½¢ç åç«¯é€»è¾‘çš„Lambda@Edge functionå…³è”ã€‚åˆ›å»ºRoute 53è®°å½•æ˜ å°„åˆ°CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä¸ºå…¨çƒç¥¨åˆ¸éªŒè¯ç³»ç»Ÿè®¾è®¡æœ€ä½å»¶è¿Ÿçš„æ¶æ„
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A/Bé€‰é¡¹ä½¿ç”¨Auroraéœ€è¦è·¨åŒºåŸŸç½‘ç»œè°ƒç”¨å¢åŠ å»¶è¿Ÿ;Cé€‰é¡¹CloudFront FunctionåŠŸèƒ½å—é™æ— æ³•å¤„ç†å¤æ‚çš„æ•°æ®åº“æ“ä½œ
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æœ€ä½å»¶è¿Ÿè¦æ±‚,å…¨çƒåˆ†å¸ƒéœ€æ±‚,è¾¹ç¼˜è®¡ç®—èƒ½åŠ›,æ•°æ®åº“å†™å…¥æ€§èƒ½
Question #427
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A medical company is running a REST API on a set of Amazon EC2 instances. The EC2 instances run in an Auto Scaling group behind an Application Load Balancer (ALB). The ALB runs in three public subnets, and the EC2 instances run in three private subnets. The company has deployed an Amazon CloudFront distribution that has the ALB as the only origin. Which solution should a solutions architect recommend to enhance the origin security?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: CloudFrontWAFEC2Auto-ScalingLambdaSystems-Manager
Knowledge Areas: å®‰å…¨æ€§ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: ç½‘ç»œéš”ç¦»æƒé™æ§åˆ¶
Exam Domain: Domain3-è®¾è®¡å®‰å…¨åº”ç”¨å’Œæ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æºç«™ä¿æŠ¤è‡ªå®šä¹‰HTTPå¤´IPç™½åå•å¯†é’¥è½®æ¢
A.
Store a random string in AWS Secrets Manager. Create an AWS Lambda function for automatic secret rotation. Configure CloudFront to inject the random string as a custom HTTP header for the origin request. Create an AWS WAF web ACL rule with a string match rule for the custom header. Associate the web ACL with the ALB.
B.
Create an AWS WAF web ACL rule with an IP match condition of the CloudFront service IP address ranges. Associate the web ACL with the ALB. Move the ALB into the three private subnets.
C.
Store a random string in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Configure Parameter Store automatic rotation for the string. Configure CloudFront to inject the random string as a custom HTTP header for the origin request. Inspect the value of the custom HTTP header, and block access in the ALB.
D.
Configure AWS Shield Advanced. Create a security group policy to allow connections from CloudFront service IP address ranges. Add the policy to AWS Shield Advanced, and attach the policy to the ALB. https://www.examtopics.com/exams/amazon/aws-certified-solutions-architect-professional-sap-c02/custom-view/ 217/269 2024/7/9 18:19 AWS Certified Solutions Architect - Professional SAP-C02 Exam - Free Exam Q&As, Page 1 | ExamTopics
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶åŒ»ç–—å…¬å¸åœ¨ä¸€ç»„Amazon EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šè¿è¡ŒREST APIã€‚EC2å®ä¾‹åœ¨Application Load Balancer (ALB)åçš„Auto Scalingç»„ä¸­è¿è¡Œã€‚ALBè¿è¡Œåœ¨ä¸‰ä¸ªå…¬æœ‰å­ç½‘ä¸­ï¼ŒEC2å®ä¾‹è¿è¡Œåœ¨ä¸‰ä¸ªç§æœ‰å­ç½‘ä¸­ã€‚å…¬å¸éƒ¨ç½²äº†ä»¥ALBä¸ºå”¯ä¸€æºç«™çš„Amazon CloudFrontåˆ†å‘ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”æ¨èå“ªç§æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¥å¢å¼ºæºç«™å®‰å…¨æ€§ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœ¨AWS Secrets Managerä¸­å­˜å‚¨éšæœºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºLambdaå‡½æ•°è¿›è¡Œè‡ªåŠ¨å¯†é’¥è½®æ¢ï¼Œé…ç½®CloudFrontæ³¨å…¥è‡ªå®šä¹‰HTTPå¤´ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºAWS WAFè§„åˆ™åŒ¹é…è‡ªå®šä¹‰å¤´å¹¶å…³è”åˆ°ALB B. åˆ›å»ºAWS WAFè§„åˆ™åŒ¹é…CloudFrontæœåŠ¡IPåœ°å€èŒƒå›´å¹¶å…³è”åˆ°ALBï¼Œå°†ALBç§»åŠ¨åˆ°ä¸‰ä¸ªç§æœ‰å­ç½‘ C. åœ¨Systems Manager Parameter Storeä¸­å­˜å‚¨éšæœºå­—ç¬¦ä¸²å¹¶é…ç½®è‡ªåŠ¨è½®æ¢ï¼Œé…ç½®CloudFrontæ³¨å…¥è‡ªå®šä¹‰HTTPå¤´ï¼Œåœ¨ALBä¸­æ£€æŸ¥å¤´å€¼å¹¶é˜»æ­¢è®¿é—® D. é…ç½®AWS Shield Advancedï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå®‰å…¨ç»„ç­–ç•¥å…è®¸CloudFrontæœåŠ¡IPèŒƒå›´è¿æ¥ï¼Œå°†ç­–ç•¥æ·»åŠ åˆ°Shield Advancedå¹¶é™„åŠ åˆ°ALB
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
å¢å¼ºCloudFrontåˆ°ALBä¹‹é—´çš„æºç«™å®‰å…¨æ€§
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
B-CloudFront IPèŒƒå›´è¿‡å¤§ä¸”ç»å¸¸å˜åŒ–ï¼ŒALBç§»åˆ°ç§æœ‰å­ç½‘ä¸å¯è¡Œï¼›C-Parameter Storeä¸æ”¯æŒè‡ªåŠ¨è½®æ¢ï¼ŒALBæ— æ³•ç›´æ¥æ£€æŸ¥HTTPå¤´ï¼›D-Shield Advancedä¸»è¦é˜²DDoSï¼Œå®‰å…¨ç»„ç­–ç•¥é…ç½®å¤æ‚ä¸”ä¸å¤Ÿç²¾ç¡®
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ç¨‹åº¦ï¼Œå®‰å…¨æ€§æœ‰æ•ˆæ€§ï¼Œå®æ–½å¯è¡Œæ€§ï¼ŒAWSæœ€ä½³å®è·µ
Question #428
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
To abide by industry regulations, a solutions architect must design a solution that will store a company's critical data in multiple public AWS Regions, including in the United States, where the company's headquarters is located. The solutions architect is required to provide access to the data stored in AWS to the company's global WAN network. The security team mandates that no traffic accessing this data should traverse the public internet. How should the solutions architect design a highly available solution that meets the requirements and is cost-effective?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: VPCRoute53
Knowledge Areas: ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–
Scenarios: è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²æ··åˆäº‘æ¶æ„
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: Direct Connectè·¨åŒºåŸŸè¿æ¥ç§æœ‰ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§
A.
Establish AWS Direct Connect connections from the company headquarters to all AWS Regions in use. Use the company WAN to send traffic over to the headquarters and then to the respective DX connection to access the data.
B.
Establish two AWS Direct Connect connections from the company headquarters to an AWS Region. Use the company WAN to send traffic over a DX connection. Use inter-region VPC peering to access the data in other AWS Regions.
C.
Establish two AWS Direct Connect connections from the company headquarters to an AWS Region. Use the company WAN to send traffic over a DX connection. Use an AWS transit VPC solution to access data in other AWS Regions.
D.
Establish two AWS Direct Connect connections from the company headquarters to an AWS Region. Use the company WAN to send traffic over a DX connection. Use Direct Connect Gateway to access data in other AWS Regions.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸ºéµå®ˆè¡Œä¸šæ³•è§„ï¼Œè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå¿…é¡»è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå°†å…¬å¸å…³é”®æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨å¤šä¸ªAWSå…¬æœ‰åŒºåŸŸï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬å…¬å¸æ€»éƒ¨æ‰€åœ¨çš„ç¾å›½ã€‚æ¶æ„å¸ˆéœ€è¦ä¸ºå…¬å¸å…¨çƒWANç½‘ç»œæä¾›è®¿é—®AWSä¸­å­˜å‚¨æ•°æ®çš„èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚å®‰å…¨å›¢é˜Ÿè¦æ±‚è®¿é—®è¿™äº›æ•°æ®çš„æµé‡ä¸å¾—é€šè¿‡å…¬å…±äº’è”ç½‘ã€‚æ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”å¦‚ä½•è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªæ»¡è¶³è¦æ±‚ä¸”æˆæœ¬æ•ˆç›Šé«˜çš„é«˜å¯ç”¨è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. ä»å…¬å¸æ€»éƒ¨åˆ°æ‰€æœ‰ä½¿ç”¨çš„AWSåŒºåŸŸå»ºç«‹Direct Connectè¿æ¥ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å…¬å¸WANå°†æµé‡å‘é€åˆ°æ€»éƒ¨ï¼Œç„¶åé€šè¿‡ç›¸åº”çš„DXè¿æ¥è®¿é—®æ•°æ® B. ä»å…¬å¸æ€»éƒ¨åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸå»ºç«‹ä¸¤ä¸ªDirect Connectè¿æ¥ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å…¬å¸WANé€šè¿‡DXè¿æ¥å‘é€æµé‡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨è·¨åŒºåŸŸVPCå¯¹ç­‰è¿æ¥è®¿é—®å…¶ä»–AWSåŒºåŸŸçš„æ•°æ® C. ä»å…¬å¸æ€»éƒ¨åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸå»ºç«‹ä¸¤ä¸ªDirect Connectè¿æ¥ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å…¬å¸WANé€šè¿‡DXè¿æ¥å‘é€æµé‡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨AWS transit VPCè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆè®¿é—®å…¶ä»–AWSåŒºåŸŸçš„æ•°æ® D. ä»å…¬å¸æ€»éƒ¨åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸå»ºç«‹ä¸¤ä¸ªDirect Connectè¿æ¥ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å…¬å¸WANé€šè¿‡DXè¿æ¥å‘é€æµé‡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Direct Connect Gatewayè®¿é—®å…¶ä»–AWSåŒºåŸŸçš„æ•°æ®
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è®¾è®¡è·¨å¤šåŒºåŸŸçš„ç§æœ‰ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œç¡®ä¿é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§å’Œæˆæœ¬æ•ˆç›Š
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aé€‰é¡¹æˆæœ¬è¿‡é«˜ï¼ˆéœ€è¦åˆ°æ¯ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸçš„DXè¿æ¥ï¼‰ï¼›Bé€‰é¡¹VPC Peeringä¸æ”¯æŒä¼ é€’è·¯ç”±ä¸”ç®¡ç†å¤æ‚ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹Transit VPCæ˜¯è¾ƒæ—§çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œå·²è¢«Direct Connect Gatewayå–ä»£
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æˆæœ¬æ•ˆç›Šã€æ¶æ„ç®€æ´æ€§ã€é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§ã€ç§æœ‰ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥è¦æ±‚
Question #429
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company has developed an application that is running Windows Server on VMware vSphere VMs that the company hosts on premises. The application data is stored in a proprietary format that must be read through the application. The company manually provisioned the servers and the application. As part of its disaster recovery plan, the company wants the ability to host its application on AWS temporarily if the company's on-premises environment becomes unavailable. The company wants the application to return to on-premises hosting after a disaster recovery event is complete. The RPO is 5 minutes. Which solution meets these requirements with the LEAST amount of operational overhead?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EC2S3EFSFSxCloudFormationSystems-Manager
Knowledge Areas: ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§å­˜å‚¨ç®¡ç†
Scenarios: æ··åˆäº‘æ¶æ„æ•°æ®å¤‡ä»½æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤RPOè¿ç»´å¼€é”€ä¸“æœ‰æ•°æ®æ ¼å¼ä¸´æ—¶æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»
A.
Configure AWS DataSync. Replicate the data to Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volumes. When the on-premises environment is unavailable, use AWS CloudFormation templates to provision Amazon EC2 instances and attach the EBS volumes.
B.
Configure AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery. Replicate the data to replication Amazon EC2 instances that are attached to Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volumes. When the on-premises environment is unavailable, use Elastic Disaster Recovery to launch EC2 instances that use the replicated volumes.
C.
Provision an AWS Storage Gateway file gateway. Replicate the data to an Amazon S3 bucket. When the on-premises environment is unavailable, use AWS Backup to restore the data to Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volumes and launch Amazon EC2 instances from these EBS volumes.
D.
Provision an Amazon FSx for Windows File Server file system on AWS. Replicate the data to the file system. When the on-premises environment is unavailable, use AWS CloudFormation templates to provision Amazon EC2 instances and use AWS::CloudFormation::Init commands to mount the Amazon FSx file shares.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸å¼€å‘äº†è¿è¡Œåœ¨VMware vSphereè™šæ‹Ÿæœºä¸Šçš„Windows Serveråº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºï¼Œæ‰˜ç®¡åœ¨æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸­ã€‚åº”ç”¨æ•°æ®ä»¥ä¸“æœ‰æ ¼å¼å­˜å‚¨ï¼Œå¿…é¡»é€šè¿‡åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè¯»å–ã€‚å…¬å¸æ‰‹åŠ¨é…ç½®äº†æœåŠ¡å™¨å’Œåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚ä½œä¸ºç¾éš¾æ¢å¤è®¡åˆ’çš„ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Œå…¬å¸å¸Œæœ›åœ¨æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸å¯ç”¨æ—¶èƒ½å¤Ÿä¸´æ—¶åœ¨AWSä¸Šæ‰˜ç®¡åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤äº‹ä»¶å®Œæˆåï¼Œåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè¦è¿”å›æœ¬åœ°æ‰˜ç®¡ã€‚RPOä¸º5åˆ†é’Ÿã€‚å“ªä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. é…ç½®AWS DataSyncï¼Œå°†æ•°æ®å¤åˆ¶åˆ°Amazon EBSå·ã€‚å½“æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸å¯ç”¨æ—¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨CloudFormationæ¨¡æ¿é…ç½®EC2å®ä¾‹å¹¶æŒ‚è½½EBSå·ã€‚ B. é…ç½®AWS Elastic Disaster Recoveryï¼Œå°†æ•°æ®å¤åˆ¶åˆ°è¿æ¥EBSå·çš„å¤åˆ¶EC2å®ä¾‹ã€‚å½“æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸å¯ç”¨æ—¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Elastic Disaster Recoveryå¯åŠ¨ä½¿ç”¨å¤åˆ¶å·çš„EC2å®ä¾‹ã€‚ C. é…ç½®AWS Storage Gatewayæ–‡ä»¶ç½‘å…³ï¼Œå°†æ•°æ®å¤åˆ¶åˆ°S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ã€‚å½“æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸å¯ç”¨æ—¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨AWS Backupå°†æ•°æ®æ¢å¤åˆ°EBSå·å¹¶ä»è¿™äº›å·å¯åŠ¨EC2å®ä¾‹ã€‚ D. åœ¨AWSä¸Šé…ç½®Amazon FSx for Windows File Serveræ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œå°†æ•°æ®å¤åˆ¶åˆ°è¯¥æ–‡ä»¶ç³»ç»Ÿã€‚å½“æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸å¯ç”¨æ—¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨CloudFormationæ¨¡æ¿é…ç½®EC2å®ä¾‹å¹¶ä½¿ç”¨CloudFormation::Initå‘½ä»¤æŒ‚è½½FSxæ–‡ä»¶å…±äº«ã€‚
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä¸ºæœ¬åœ°VMwareç¯å¢ƒè®¾è®¡AWSç¾éš¾æ¢å¤è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œæ»¡è¶³5åˆ†é’ŸRPOä¸”è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aç¼ºä¹è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ï¼ŒCæ¶‰åŠä¸å¿…è¦çš„å¤‡ä»½æ¢å¤æ­¥éª¤ï¼ŒDä¸é€‚åˆä¸“æœ‰æ ¼å¼æ•°æ®ä¸”å¤æ‚åº¦é«˜
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–ï¼Œæ»¡è¶³RPOè¦æ±‚ï¼Œæ”¯æŒVMwareåˆ°AWSçš„ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤
Question #430
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company runs a highly available data collection application on Amazon EC2 in the eu-north-1 Region. The application collects data from end-user devices and writes records to an Amazon Kinesis data stream and a set of AWS Lambda functions that process the records. The company persists the output of the record processing to an Amazon S3 bucket in eu-north-1. The company uses the data in the S3 bucket as a data source for Amazon Athena. The company wants to increase its global presence. A solutions architect must launch the data collection capabilities in the sa-east-1 and ap-northeast-1 Regions. The solutions architect deploys the application, the Kinesis data stream, and the Lambda functions in the two new Regions. The solutions architect keeps the S3 bucket in eu-north-1 to meet a requirement to centralize the data analysis. During testing of the new setup, the solutions architect notices a significant lag on the arrival of data from the new Regions to the S3 bucket. Which solution will improve this lag time the MOST?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: S3LambdaEC2Kinesis
Knowledge Areas: æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„å­˜å‚¨ç®¡ç†
Scenarios: è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²æ€§èƒ½è°ƒä¼˜
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: S3ä¼ è¾“åŠ é€Ÿè·¨åŒºåŸŸå¤åˆ¶ç½‘ç»œå»¶è¿Ÿä¼˜åŒ–å…¨çƒæ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“
A.
In each of the two new Regions, set up the Lambda functions to run in a VPC. Set up an S3 gateway endpoint in that VPC.
B.
Turn on S3 Transfer Acceleration on the S3 bucket in eu-north-1. Change the application to use the new S3 accelerated endpoint when the application uploads data to the S3 bucket.
C.
Create an S3 bucket in each of the two new Regions. Set the application in each new Region to upload to its respective S3 bucket. Set up S3 Cross-Region Replication to replicate data to the S3 bucket in eu-north-1.
D.
Increase the memory requirements of the Lambda functions to ensure that they have multiple cores available. Use the multipart upload feature when the application uploads data to Amazon S3 from Lambda.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨eu-north-1åŒºåŸŸçš„Amazon EC2ä¸Šè¿è¡Œé«˜å¯ç”¨æ•°æ®æ”¶é›†åº”ç”¨ã€‚åº”ç”¨ä»ç»ˆç«¯ç”¨æˆ·è®¾å¤‡æ”¶é›†æ•°æ®å¹¶å†™å…¥Amazon Kinesisæ•°æ®æµå’Œä¸€ç»„å¤„ç†è®°å½•çš„AWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°ã€‚å…¬å¸å°†è®°å½•å¤„ç†è¾“å‡ºæŒä¹…åŒ–åˆ°eu-north-1çš„Amazon S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ä¸­ï¼Œå¹¶å°†S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ä¸­çš„æ•°æ®ä½œä¸ºAmazon Athenaçš„æ•°æ®æºã€‚å…¬å¸å¸Œæœ›æ‰©å¤§å…¨çƒä¸šåŠ¡ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå¿…é¡»åœ¨sa-east-1å’Œap-northeast-1åŒºåŸŸå¯åŠ¨æ•°æ®æ”¶é›†åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚æ¶æ„å¸ˆåœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªæ–°åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²äº†åº”ç”¨ã€Kinesisæ•°æ®æµå’ŒLambdaå‡½æ•°ï¼Œä½†ä¸ºæ»¡è¶³é›†ä¸­æ•°æ®åˆ†æçš„è¦æ±‚ï¼ŒS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ä»ä¿ç•™åœ¨eu-north-1ã€‚åœ¨æµ‹è¯•æ–°è®¾ç½®æ—¶ï¼Œæ¶æ„å¸ˆæ³¨æ„åˆ°ä»æ–°åŒºåŸŸåˆ°S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶çš„æ•°æ®åˆ°è¾¾å­˜åœ¨æ˜¾è‘—å»¶è¿Ÿã€‚å“ªç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆèƒ½æœ€å¤§ç¨‹åº¦æ”¹å–„è¿™ç§å»¶è¿Ÿï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªæ–°åŒºåŸŸä¸­ï¼Œè®¾ç½®Lambdaå‡½æ•°åœ¨VPCä¸­è¿è¡Œï¼Œåœ¨è¯¥VPCä¸­è®¾ç½®S3ç½‘å…³ç«¯ç‚¹ B. åœ¨eu-north-1çš„S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ä¸Šå¯ç”¨S3ä¼ è¾“åŠ é€Ÿï¼Œæ›´æ”¹åº”ç”¨ä½¿ç”¨æ–°çš„S3åŠ é€Ÿç«¯ç‚¹ä¸Šä¼ æ•°æ® C. åœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªæ–°åŒºåŸŸå„åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ï¼Œè®¾ç½®å„åŒºåŸŸåº”ç”¨ä¸Šä¼ åˆ°å„è‡ªçš„S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ï¼Œè®¾ç½®S3è·¨åŒºåŸŸå¤åˆ¶åˆ°eu-north-1çš„S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ D. å¢åŠ Lambdaå‡½æ•°çš„å†…å­˜è¦æ±‚ç¡®ä¿æœ‰å¤šæ ¸å¯ç”¨ï¼Œä»Lambdaä¸Šä¼ æ•°æ®åˆ°S3æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨å¤šéƒ¨åˆ†ä¸Šä¼ åŠŸèƒ½
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³è·¨åŒºåŸŸæ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“åˆ°é›†ä¸­S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶çš„å»¶è¿Ÿé—®é¢˜
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-VPCå’ŒS3ç½‘å…³ç«¯ç‚¹ä¸è§£å†³è·¨åŒºåŸŸå»¶è¿Ÿé—®é¢˜ï¼›B-ä¼ è¾“åŠ é€Ÿæœ‰å¸®åŠ©ä½†ä¸å¦‚æœ¬åœ°å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶æ•ˆæœæ˜¾è‘—ï¼›D-å¢åŠ Lambdaå†…å­˜å’Œå¤šéƒ¨åˆ†ä¸Šä¼ ä¸èƒ½è§£å†³ç½‘ç»œå»¶è¿Ÿæ ¹æœ¬é—®é¢˜
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æœ€å¤§ç¨‹åº¦å‡å°‘è·¨åŒºåŸŸæ•°æ®ä¼ è¾“å»¶è¿Ÿçš„åŒæ—¶ä¿æŒæ•°æ®é›†ä¸­åˆ†æèƒ½åŠ›
Question #431
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A company provides a centralized Amazon EC2 application hosted in a single shared VPC. The centralized application must be accessible from client applications running in the VPCs of other business units. The centralized application front end is configured with a Network Load Balancer (NLB) for scalability. Up to 10 business unit VPCs will need to be connected to the shared VPC. Some of the business unit VPC CIDR blocks overlap with the shared VPC, and some overlap with each other. Network connectivity to the centralized application in the shared VPC should be allowed from authorized business unit VPCs only. Which network configuration should a solutions architect use to provide connectivity from the client applications in the business unit VPCs to the centralized application in the shared VPC?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: VPCEC2Auto-Scaling
Knowledge Areas: ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„å®‰å…¨æ€§æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: ç½‘ç»œéš”ç¦»è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: CIDRé‡å VPC endpoint serviceç½‘ç»œéš”ç¦»æˆæƒè®¿é—®
A.
Create an AWS Transit Gateway. Attach the shared VPC and the authorized business unit VPCs to the transit gateway. Create a single transit gateway route table and associate it with all of the attached VPCs. Allow automatic propagation of routes from the attachments into the route table. Configure VPC routing tables to send traffic to the transit gateway.
B.
Create a VPC endpoint service using the centralized application NLB and enable the option to require endpoint acceptance. Create a VPC endpoint in each of the business unit VPCs using the service name of the endpoint service. Accept authorized endpoint requests from the endpoint service console.
C.
Create a VPC peering connection from each business unit VPC to the shared VPC. Accept the VPC peering connections from the shared VPC console. Configure VPC routing tables to send traffic to the VPC peering connection.
D.
Configure a virtual private gateway for the shared VPC and create customer gateways for each of the authorized business unit VPCs. Establish a Site-to-Site VPN connection from the business unit VPCs to the shared VPC. Configure VPC routing tables to send traffic to the VPN connection.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨å•ä¸ªå…±äº«VPCä¸­æä¾›é›†ä¸­å¼Amazon EC2åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚é›†ä¸­å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå¿…é¡»èƒ½å¤Ÿä»å…¶ä»–ä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCä¸­è¿è¡Œçš„å®¢æˆ·ç«¯åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè®¿é—®ã€‚é›†ä¸­å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå‰ç«¯é…ç½®äº†Network Load Balancer (NLB)ä»¥å®ç°å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§ã€‚æœ€å¤šéœ€è¦å°†10ä¸ªä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCè¿æ¥åˆ°å…±äº«VPCã€‚ä¸€äº›ä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPC CIDRå—ä¸å…±äº«VPCé‡å ï¼Œä¸€äº›å½¼æ­¤é‡å ã€‚åªåº”å…è®¸æˆæƒçš„ä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCè®¿é—®å…±äº«VPCä¸­çš„é›†ä¸­å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”ä½¿ç”¨å“ªç§ç½‘ç»œé…ç½®æ¥æä¾›ä»ä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCä¸­çš„å®¢æˆ·ç«¯åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºåˆ°å…±äº«VPCä¸­é›†ä¸­å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºçš„è¿æ¥ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºAWS Transit Gatewayï¼Œå°†å…±äº«VPCå’Œæˆæƒä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCè¿æ¥åˆ°transit gatewayï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå•ä¸ªè·¯ç”±è¡¨å¹¶å…³è”æ‰€æœ‰VPCï¼Œå…è®¸è‡ªåŠ¨è·¯ç”±ä¼ æ’­ B. ä½¿ç”¨é›†ä¸­å¼åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºNLBåˆ›å»ºVPC endpoint serviceå¹¶å¯ç”¨éœ€è¦endpointæ¥å—é€‰é¡¹ï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ªä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCä¸­åˆ›å»ºVPC endpointï¼Œä»endpoint serviceæ§åˆ¶å°æ¥å—æˆæƒè¯·æ±‚ C. ä»æ¯ä¸ªä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCåˆ°å…±äº«VPCåˆ›å»ºVPC peeringè¿æ¥ï¼Œä»å…±äº«VPCæ§åˆ¶å°æ¥å—peeringè¿æ¥ï¼Œé…ç½®VPCè·¯ç”±è¡¨ D. ä¸ºå…±äº«VPCé…ç½®virtual private gatewayï¼Œä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªæˆæƒä¸šåŠ¡å•å…ƒVPCåˆ›å»ºcustomer gatewayï¼Œå»ºç«‹Site-to-Site VPNè¿æ¥
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³CIDRé‡å é—®é¢˜å¹¶æä¾›å®‰å…¨çš„è·¨VPCè®¿é—®
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-Transit Gatewayä¸èƒ½è§£å†³CIDRé‡å é—®é¢˜ï¼›C-VPC peeringä¸æ”¯æŒCIDRé‡å ï¼›D-Site-to-Site VPNè¿‡äºå¤æ‚ä¸”ä¸é€‚ç”¨äºVPCé—´è¿æ¥
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
CIDRé‡å é™åˆ¶ã€è®¿é—®æ§åˆ¶éœ€æ±‚ã€æ¶æ„å¤æ‚æ€§
Question #432
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company wants to migrate its website to AWS. The website uses microservices and runs on containers that are deployed in an on-premises, self-managed Kubernetes cluster. All the manifests that define the deployments for the containers in the Kubernetes deployment are in source control. All data for the website is stored in a PostgreSQL database. An open source container image repository runs alongside the on-premises environment. A solutions architect needs to determine the architecture that the company will use for the website on AWS. Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST effort to migrate?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EKSECSEC2RDSECR
Knowledge Areas: å®¹å™¨åŒ–è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: Kubernetesè¿ç§»å®¹å™¨ç¼–æ’æ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡æ¸…å•æ–‡ä»¶å¤ç”¨
A.
Create an AWS App Runner service. Connect the App Runner service to the open source container image repository. Deploy the manifests from on premises to the App Runner service. Create an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL database.
B.
Create an Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) cluster that has managed node groups. Copy the application containers to a new Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR) repository. Deploy the manifests from on premises to the EKS cluster. Create an Amazon Aurora PostgreSQL DB cluster.
C.
Create an Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) cluster that has an Amazon EC2 capacity pool. Copy the application containers to a new Amazon Elastic Container Registry (Amazon ECR) repository. Register each container image as a new task definition. Configure ECS services to run the tasks. Create an Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL database. services for each task definition to match the original Kubernetes deployments. Create an Amazon Aurora PostgreSQL DB cluster.
D.
Rebuild the on-premises Kubernetes cluster by hosting the cluster on Amazon EC2 instances. Migrate the open source container image repository to the EC2 instances. Deploy the manifests from on premises to the new cluster on AWS. Deploy an open source PostgreSQL database on the new cluster.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸æƒ³è¦å°†å…¶ç½‘ç«™è¿ç§»åˆ°AWSã€‚è¯¥ç½‘ç«™ä½¿ç”¨å¾®æœåŠ¡æ¶æ„ï¼Œè¿è¡Œåœ¨éƒ¨ç½²äºæœ¬åœ°è‡ªç®¡ç†Kubernetesé›†ç¾¤çš„å®¹å™¨ä¸­ã€‚å®šä¹‰å®¹å™¨éƒ¨ç½²çš„æ‰€æœ‰Kubernetesæ¸…å•æ–‡ä»¶éƒ½åœ¨æºä»£ç æ§åˆ¶ä¸­ã€‚ç½‘ç«™çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨PostgreSQLæ•°æ®åº“ä¸­ã€‚å¼€æºå®¹å™¨é•œåƒä»“åº“ä¸æœ¬åœ°ç¯å¢ƒä¸€èµ·è¿è¡Œã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆéœ€è¦ç¡®å®šå…¬å¸åœ¨AWSä¸Šä½¿ç”¨çš„ç½‘ç«™æ¶æ„ã€‚å“ªç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„è¿ç§»å·¥ä½œé‡æ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºAWS App RunneræœåŠ¡ï¼Œè¿æ¥åˆ°å¼€æºå®¹å™¨é•œåƒä»“åº“ï¼Œéƒ¨ç½²æœ¬åœ°æ¸…å•æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºAmazon RDS for PostgreSQLæ•°æ®åº“ B. åˆ›å»ºå¸¦æ‰˜ç®¡èŠ‚ç‚¹ç»„çš„Amazon EKSé›†ç¾¤ï¼Œå¤åˆ¶å®¹å™¨åˆ°æ–°çš„Amazon ECRä»“åº“ï¼Œéƒ¨ç½²æœ¬åœ°æ¸…å•æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºAmazon Aurora PostgreSQLé›†ç¾¤ C. åˆ›å»ºå¸¦EC2å®¹é‡æ± çš„Amazon ECSé›†ç¾¤ï¼Œå¤åˆ¶å®¹å™¨åˆ°æ–°çš„Amazon ECRä»“åº“ï¼Œæ³¨å†Œå®¹å™¨é•œåƒä¸ºä»»åŠ¡å®šä¹‰ï¼Œé…ç½®ECSæœåŠ¡ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºAmazon RDS for PostgreSQLæ•°æ®åº“ D. åœ¨Amazon EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šé‡å»ºæœ¬åœ°Kubernetesé›†ç¾¤ï¼Œè¿ç§»å¼€æºå®¹å™¨é•œåƒä»“åº“ï¼Œéƒ¨ç½²æ¸…å•æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œéƒ¨ç½²å¼€æºPostgreSQLæ•°æ®åº“
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä»¥æœ€å°‘å·¥ä½œé‡å°†åŸºäºKubernetesçš„å¾®æœåŠ¡ç½‘ç«™è¿ç§»åˆ°AWS
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aé€‰é¡¹App Runnerä¸æ”¯æŒKubernetesæ¸…å•ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹ECSéœ€è¦é‡å†™éƒ¨ç½²é…ç½®ï¼Œå·¥ä½œé‡å¤§ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹è‡ªç®¡ç†é›†ç¾¤å¢åŠ è¿ç»´å¤æ‚åº¦ï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆæœ€å°‘å·¥ä½œé‡è¦æ±‚
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è¿ç§»å·¥ä½œé‡æœ€å°åŒ–ï¼Œç°æœ‰Kubernetesèµ„äº§å¤ç”¨ç¨‹åº¦ï¼Œæ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡ä¼˜åŠ¿
Question #433
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company uses a mobile app on AWS to run online contests. The company selects a winner at random at the end of each contest. The contests run for variable lengths of time. The company does not need to retain any data from a contest after the contest is finished. The company uses custom code that is hosted on Amazon EC2 instances to process the contest data and select a winner. The EC2 instances run behind an Application Load Balancer and store contest entries on Amazon RDS DB instances. The company must design a new architecture to reduce the cost of running the contests. Which solution will meet these requirements MOST cost-effectively?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: LambdaDynamoDBECSFargateRDSElastiCache+1 more
Knowledge Areas: æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: æˆæœ¬åˆ†æè‡ªåŠ¨æ‰©å±•
Exam Domain: Domain4-è®¾è®¡æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¶æ„TTLè‡ªåŠ¨è¿‡æœŸæˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æŒ‰éœ€è®¡è´¹
A.
Migrate storage of the contest entries to Amazon DynamoDB. Create a DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX) cluster. Rewrite the code to run as Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) containers that use the Fargate launch type. At the end of the contest, delete the DynamoDB table.
B.
Migrate the storage of the contest entries to Amazon Redshift. Rewrite the code as AWS Lambda functions. At the end of the contest, delete the Redshift cluster.
C.
Add an Amazon ElastiCache for Redis cluster in front of the RDS DB instances to cache the contest entries. Rewrite the code to run as Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS) containers that use the Fargate launch type. Set the ElastiCache TTL attribute on each entry to expire each entry at the end of the contest.
D.
Migrate the storage of the contest entries to Amazon DynamoDB. Rewrite the code as AWS Lambda functions. Set the DynamoDB TTL attribute on each entry to expire each entry at the end of the contest.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨AWSä¸Šä½¿ç”¨ç§»åŠ¨åº”ç”¨è¿è¡Œåœ¨çº¿ç«èµ›ã€‚å…¬å¸åœ¨æ¯æ¬¡ç«èµ›ç»“æŸæ—¶éšæœºé€‰æ‹©è·èƒœè€…ã€‚ç«èµ›è¿è¡Œæ—¶é—´é•¿åº¦å¯å˜ã€‚ç«èµ›ç»“æŸåå…¬å¸ä¸éœ€è¦ä¿ç•™ä»»ä½•ç«èµ›æ•°æ®ã€‚å…¬å¸ä½¿ç”¨æ‰˜ç®¡åœ¨Amazon EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šçš„è‡ªå®šä¹‰ä»£ç æ¥å¤„ç†ç«èµ›æ•°æ®å¹¶é€‰æ‹©è·èƒœè€…ã€‚EC2å®ä¾‹è¿è¡Œåœ¨Application Load Balanceråé¢ï¼Œå¹¶å°†ç«èµ›æ¡ç›®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨Amazon RDS DBå®ä¾‹ä¸Šã€‚å…¬å¸å¿…é¡»è®¾è®¡æ–°æ¶æ„ä»¥é™ä½è¿è¡Œç«èµ›çš„æˆæœ¬ã€‚
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å°†ç«èµ›æ¡ç›®å­˜å‚¨è¿ç§»åˆ°Amazon DynamoDBã€‚åˆ›å»ºDynamoDB Accelerator (DAX)é›†ç¾¤ã€‚é‡å†™ä»£ç ä¸ºä½¿ç”¨Fargateå¯åŠ¨ç±»å‹çš„Amazon ECSå®¹å™¨ã€‚ç«èµ›ç»“æŸæ—¶åˆ é™¤DynamoDBè¡¨ã€‚ B. å°†ç«èµ›æ¡ç›®å­˜å‚¨è¿ç§»åˆ°Amazon Redshiftã€‚é‡å†™ä»£ç ä¸ºAWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°ã€‚ç«èµ›ç»“æŸæ—¶åˆ é™¤Redshifté›†ç¾¤ã€‚ C. åœ¨RDS DBå®ä¾‹å‰æ·»åŠ Amazon ElastiCache for Redisé›†ç¾¤æ¥ç¼“å­˜ç«èµ›æ¡ç›®ã€‚é‡å†™ä»£ç ä¸ºä½¿ç”¨Fargateå¯åŠ¨ç±»å‹çš„Amazon ECSå®¹å™¨ã€‚åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ç›®ä¸Šè®¾ç½®ElastiCache TTLå±æ€§ï¼Œä½¿æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ç›®åœ¨ç«èµ›ç»“æŸæ—¶è¿‡æœŸã€‚ D. å°†ç«èµ›æ¡ç›®å­˜å‚¨è¿ç§»åˆ°Amazon DynamoDBã€‚é‡å†™ä»£ç ä¸ºAWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°ã€‚åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ç›®ä¸Šè®¾ç½®DynamoDB TTLå±æ€§ï¼Œä½¿æ¯ä¸ªæ¡ç›®åœ¨ç«èµ›ç»“æŸæ—¶è¿‡æœŸã€‚
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è®¾è®¡æœ€å…·æˆæœ¬æ•ˆç›Šçš„æ¶æ„æ¥è¿è¡Œå¯å˜æ—¶é•¿çš„åœ¨çº¿ç«èµ›
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aé€‰é¡¹DAXå¢åŠ ä¸å¿…è¦æˆæœ¬ï¼›Bé€‰é¡¹Redshifté€‚åˆæ•°æ®ä»“åº“è€Œéç®€å•ç«èµ›æ•°æ®ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹ä»ä½¿ç”¨RDSå’Œç¼“å­˜å¢åŠ å¤æ‚æ€§å’Œæˆæœ¬
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æœ€ä½è¿è¥æˆæœ¬ã€æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¶æ„ã€è‡ªåŠ¨æ•°æ®æ¸…ç†èƒ½åŠ›
Question #434
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company has implemented a new security requirement. According to the new requirement, the company must scan all traffic from corporate AWS instances in the company's VPC for violations of the company's security policies. As a result of these scans, the company can block access to and from specific IP addresses. To meet the new requirement, the company deploys a set of Amazon EC2 instances in private subnets to serve as transparent proxies. The company installs approved proxy server software on these EC2 instances. The company modifies the route tables on all subnets to use the corresponding EC2 instances with proxy software as the default route. The company also creates security groups that are compliant with the security policies and assigns these security groups to the EC2 instances. Despite these configurations, the traffic of the EC2 instances in their private subnets is not being properly forwarded to the internet. What should a solutions architect do to resolve this issue?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EC2VPC
Knowledge Areas: ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„å®‰å…¨æ€§æ•…éšœæ’é™¤
Scenarios: ç½‘ç»œéš”ç¦»æƒé™æ§åˆ¶
Exam Domain: Domain3-è®¾è®¡å®‰å…¨åº”ç”¨å’Œæ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æº/ç›®æ ‡æ£€æŸ¥é€æ˜ä»£ç†è·¯ç”±è¡¨ç½‘ç»œè½¬å‘
A.
Disable source/destination checks on the EC2 instances that run the proxy software.
B.
Add a rule to the security group that is assigned to the proxy EC2 instances to allow all traffic between instances that have this security group. Assign this security group to all EC2 instances in the VPC.
C.
Change the VPC's DHCP options set. Set the DNS server options to point to the addresses of the proxy EC2 instances.
D.
Assign one additional elastic network interface to each proxy EC2 instance. Ensure that one of these network interfaces has a route to the private subnets. Ensure that the other network interface has a route to the internet.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸å®æ–½äº†æ–°çš„å®‰å…¨è¦æ±‚ã€‚æ ¹æ®æ–°è¦æ±‚ï¼Œå…¬å¸å¿…é¡»æ‰«æVPCä¸­æ‰€æœ‰ä¼ä¸šAWSå®ä¾‹çš„æµé‡ï¼Œæ£€æŸ¥æ˜¯å¦è¿åå…¬å¸å®‰å…¨ç­–ç•¥ã€‚åŸºäºæ‰«æç»“æœï¼Œå…¬å¸å¯ä»¥é˜»æ­¢ç‰¹å®šIPåœ°å€çš„è®¿é—®ã€‚ä¸ºæ»¡è¶³æ–°è¦æ±‚ï¼Œå…¬å¸åœ¨ç§æœ‰å­ç½‘ä¸­éƒ¨ç½²äº†ä¸€ç»„EC2å®ä¾‹ä½œä¸ºé€æ˜ä»£ç†ã€‚å…¬å¸åœ¨è¿™äº›EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šå®‰è£…äº†æ‰¹å‡†çš„ä»£ç†æœåŠ¡å™¨è½¯ä»¶ã€‚å…¬å¸ä¿®æ”¹äº†æ‰€æœ‰å­ç½‘çš„è·¯ç”±è¡¨ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åº”çš„ä»£ç†è½¯ä»¶EC2å®ä¾‹ä½œä¸ºé»˜è®¤è·¯ç”±ã€‚å…¬å¸è¿˜åˆ›å»ºäº†ç¬¦åˆå®‰å…¨ç­–ç•¥çš„å®‰å…¨ç»„å¹¶åˆ†é…ç»™EC2å®ä¾‹ã€‚å°½ç®¡è¿›è¡Œäº†è¿™äº›é…ç½®ï¼Œç§æœ‰å­ç½‘ä¸­EC2å®ä¾‹çš„æµé‡ä»æ— æ³•æ­£ç¡®è½¬å‘åˆ°äº’è”ç½‘ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”è¯¥å¦‚ä½•è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœ¨è¿è¡Œä»£ç†è½¯ä»¶çš„EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šç¦ç”¨æº/ç›®æ ‡æ£€æŸ¥ B. åœ¨åˆ†é…ç»™ä»£ç†EC2å®ä¾‹çš„å®‰å…¨ç»„ä¸­æ·»åŠ è§„åˆ™ï¼Œå…è®¸å…·æœ‰æ­¤å®‰å…¨ç»„çš„å®ä¾‹ä¹‹é—´çš„æ‰€æœ‰æµé‡ã€‚å°†æ­¤å®‰å…¨ç»„åˆ†é…ç»™VPCä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰EC2å®ä¾‹ C. æ›´æ”¹VPCçš„DHCPé€‰é¡¹é›†ã€‚å°†DNSæœåŠ¡å™¨é€‰é¡¹è®¾ç½®ä¸ºæŒ‡å‘ä»£ç†EC2å®ä¾‹çš„åœ°å€ D. ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªä»£ç†EC2å®ä¾‹åˆ†é…ä¸€ä¸ªé¢å¤–çš„å¼¹æ€§ç½‘ç»œæ¥å£ã€‚ç¡®ä¿å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªç½‘ç»œæ¥å£æœ‰åˆ°ç§æœ‰å­ç½‘çš„è·¯ç”±ã€‚ç¡®ä¿å¦ä¸€ä¸ªç½‘ç»œæ¥å£æœ‰åˆ°äº’è”ç½‘çš„è·¯ç”±
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³EC2ä»£ç†å®ä¾‹æ— æ³•æ­£ç¡®è½¬å‘æµé‡åˆ°äº’è”ç½‘çš„é—®é¢˜
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Bé€‰é¡¹åªè§£å†³å®‰å…¨ç»„é—®é¢˜ä½†ä¸è§£å†³è½¬å‘é—®é¢˜ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹DNSè®¾ç½®ä¸æµé‡è½¬å‘æ— å…³ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹è¿‡äºå¤æ‚ä¸”ä¸å¿…è¦ï¼Œå•ä¸ªç½‘ç»œæ¥å£é…åˆæ­£ç¡®çš„è·¯ç”±è¡¨å³å¯
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
ç†è§£EC2å®ä¾‹ä½œä¸ºç½‘ç»œä¸­ä»‹è®¾å¤‡æ—¶éœ€è¦ç¦ç”¨æº/ç›®æ ‡æ£€æŸ¥çš„ç½‘ç»œåŸºç¡€çŸ¥è¯†
Question #435
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company is running its solution on AWS in a manually created VPC. The company is using AWS CloudFormation to provision other parts of the infrastructure. According to a new requirement, the company must manage all infrastructure in an automatic way. What should the company do to meet this new requirement with the LEAST effort?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: CloudFormationVPC
Knowledge Areas: è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: èµ„æºå¯¼å…¥åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½å³ä»£ç CloudFormationå †æ ˆç®¡ç†
A.
Create a new AWS Cloud Development Kit (AWS CDK) stack that strictly provisions the existing VPC resources and configuration. Use AWS CDK to import the VPC into the stack and to manage the VPC.
B.
Create a CloudFormation stack set that creates the VPC. Use the stack set to import the VPC into the stack.
C.
Create a new CloudFormation template that strictly provisions the existing VPC resources and configuration. From the CloudFormation console, create a new stack by importing the existing resources.
D.
Create a new CloudFormation template that creates the VPC. Use the AWS Serverless Application Model (AWS SAM) CLI to import the VPC.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨AWSä¸Šçš„æ‰‹åŠ¨åˆ›å»ºçš„VPCä¸­è¿è¡Œå…¶è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚è¯¥å…¬å¸æ­£åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨AWS CloudFormationæ¥é…ç½®åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½çš„å…¶ä»–éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚æ ¹æ®æ–°è¦æ±‚ï¼Œå…¬å¸å¿…é¡»ä»¥è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æ–¹å¼ç®¡ç†æ‰€æœ‰åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ã€‚å…¬å¸åº”è¯¥å¦‚ä½•ä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„åŠªåŠ›æ»¡è¶³è¿™ä¸€æ–°è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„AWS CDKå †æ ˆæ¥ä¸¥æ ¼é…ç½®ç°æœ‰VPCèµ„æºå’Œé…ç½®ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨CDKå¯¼å…¥VPCåˆ°å †æ ˆä¸­è¿›è¡Œç®¡ç† B. åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªCloudFormationå †æ ˆé›†æ¥åˆ›å»ºVPCï¼Œä½¿ç”¨å †æ ˆé›†å°†VPCå¯¼å…¥åˆ°å †æ ˆä¸­ C. åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„CloudFormationæ¨¡æ¿æ¥ä¸¥æ ¼é…ç½®ç°æœ‰VPCèµ„æºå’Œé…ç½®ï¼Œä»CloudFormationæ§åˆ¶å°é€šè¿‡å¯¼å…¥ç°æœ‰èµ„æºåˆ›å»ºæ–°å †æ ˆ D. åˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„CloudFormationæ¨¡æ¿æ¥åˆ›å»ºVPCï¼Œä½¿ç”¨AWS SAM CLIå¯¼å…¥VPC
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
å°†æ‰‹åŠ¨åˆ›å»ºçš„VPCçº³å…¥è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ç®¡ç†
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-CDKå¯¼å…¥åŠŸèƒ½å¤æ‚åº¦è¾ƒé«˜ï¼›B-å †æ ˆé›†ç”¨äºå¤šè´¦æˆ·/åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²ï¼Œä¸é€‚ç”¨äºå•ä¸ªVPCå¯¼å…¥ï¼›D-SAMä¸»è¦ç”¨äºæ— æœåŠ¡å™¨åº”ç”¨ï¼Œä¸æ”¯æŒVPCå¯¼å…¥
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æœ€å°‘åŠªåŠ›åŸåˆ™ï¼Œç°æœ‰èµ„æºå¯¼å…¥èƒ½åŠ›ï¼Œå·¥å…·é€‚ç”¨æ€§
Question #436
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company has developed a new release of a popular video game and wants to make it available for public download. The new release package is approximately 5 GB in size. The company provides downloads for existing releases from a Linux-based, publicly facing FTP site hosted in an on-premises data center. The company expects the new release will be downloaded by users worldwide. The company wants a solution that provides improved download performance and low transfer costs, regardless of a user's location.
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: S3CloudFrontRoute53EC2EFSAuto-Scaling
Knowledge Areas: æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: å…¨çƒå†…å®¹åˆ†å‘CDNç¼“å­˜é™æ€å†…å®¹æ‰˜ç®¡è¾¹ç¼˜ä½ç½®
A.
Store the game files on Amazon EBS volumes mounted on Amazon EC2 instances within an Auto Scaling group. Configure an FTP service on the EC2 instances. Use an Application Load Balancer in front of the Auto Scaling group. Publish the game download URL for users to download the package.
B.
Store the game files on Amazon EFS volumes that are attached to Amazon EC2 instances within an Auto Scaling group. Configure an FTP service on each of the EC2 instances. Use an Application Load Balancer in front of the Auto Scaling group. Publish the game download URL for users to download the package.
C.
Configure Amazon Route 53 and an Amazon S3 bucket for website hosting. Upload the game files to the S3 bucket. Use Amazon CloudFront for the website. Publish the game download URL for users to download the package.
D.
Configure Amazon Route 53 and an Amazon S3 bucket for website hosting. Upload the game files to the S3 bucket. Set Requester Pays for the S3 bucket. Publish the game download URL for users to download the package.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸å¼€å‘äº†çƒ­é—¨è§†é¢‘æ¸¸æˆçš„æ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œå¸Œæœ›æä¾›å…¬å¼€ä¸‹è½½ã€‚æ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬åŒ…å¤§çº¦5GBå¤§å°ã€‚å…¬å¸ç›®å‰é€šè¿‡æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒçš„Linux FTPç«™ç‚¹æä¾›ç°æœ‰ç‰ˆæœ¬ä¸‹è½½ã€‚å…¬å¸é¢„æœŸæ–°ç‰ˆæœ¬å°†è¢«å…¨çƒç”¨æˆ·ä¸‹è½½ã€‚å…¬å¸éœ€è¦ä¸€ä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œæ— è®ºç”¨æˆ·ä½ç½®å¦‚ä½•ï¼Œéƒ½èƒ½æä¾›æ”¹è¿›çš„ä¸‹è½½æ€§èƒ½å’Œä½ä¼ è¾“æˆæœ¬ã€‚
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å°†æ¸¸æˆæ–‡ä»¶å­˜å‚¨åœ¨Auto Scalingç»„å†…EC2å®ä¾‹æŒ‚è½½çš„EBSå·ä¸Šï¼Œé…ç½®FTPæœåŠ¡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Application Load Balancer B. å°†æ¸¸æˆæ–‡ä»¶å­˜å‚¨åœ¨Auto Scalingç»„å†…EC2å®ä¾‹é™„åŠ çš„EFSå·ä¸Šï¼Œé…ç½®FTPæœåŠ¡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Application Load Balancer C. é…ç½®Route 53å’ŒS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶è¿›è¡Œç½‘ç«™æ‰˜ç®¡ï¼Œä¸Šä¼ æ¸¸æˆæ–‡ä»¶åˆ°S3ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨CloudFront D. é…ç½®Route 53å’ŒS3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶è¿›è¡Œç½‘ç«™æ‰˜ç®¡ï¼Œä¸Šä¼ æ¸¸æˆæ–‡ä»¶åˆ°S3ï¼Œè®¾ç½®è¯·æ±‚è€…ä»˜è´¹
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä¸ºå…¨çƒç”¨æˆ·æä¾›5GBæ¸¸æˆæ–‡ä»¶çš„é«˜æ€§èƒ½ä½æˆæœ¬ä¸‹è½½è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆ
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A/Béœ€è¦ç®¡ç†EC2åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ï¼Œæˆæœ¬é«˜ä¸”æ€§èƒ½ä¸å¦‚CDNï¼›Dçš„è¯·æ±‚è€…ä»˜è´¹ä¼šå°†æˆæœ¬è½¬å«ç»™ç”¨æˆ·ï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆå…¬å¸æ‰¿æ‹…ä¼ è¾“æˆæœ¬çš„éœ€æ±‚
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
å…¨çƒæ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–éœ€æ±‚ï¼Œé™æ€å†…å®¹åˆ†å‘ç‰¹æ€§ï¼Œæˆæœ¬æ•ˆç›Šè€ƒè™‘
Question #437
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company runs an application in the cloud that consists of a database and a website. Users can post data to the website, have the data processed, and have the data sent back to them in an email. Data is stored in a MySQL database running on an Amazon EC2 instance. The database is running in a VPC with two private subnets. The website is running on Apache Tomcat in a single EC2 instance in a different VPC with one public subnet. There is a single VPC peering connection between the database and website VPC. The website has suffered several outages during the last month due to high traffic. Which actions should a solutions architect take to increase the reliability of the application? (Choose three.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EC2VPCAuto-ScalingRDSRoute53
Knowledge Areas: é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–
Scenarios: è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡è‡ªåŠ¨æ‰©å±•æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§æ¶æ„æ•°æ®åº“å†—ä½™è´Ÿè½½åˆ†å‘å¤šå¯ç”¨åŒºéƒ¨ç½²
A.
Place the Tomcat server in an Auto Scaling group with multiple EC2 instances behind an Application Load Balancer.
B.
Provision an additional VPC peering connection.
C.
Migrate the MySQL database to Amazon Aurora with one Aurora Replica.
D.
Provision two NAT gateways in the database VPC.
E.
Move the Tomcat server to the database VPC.
F.
Create an additional public subnet in a different Availability Zone in the website VPC.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸åœ¨äº‘ä¸­è¿è¡Œä¸€ä¸ªåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºï¼ŒåŒ…å«æ•°æ®åº“å’Œç½‘ç«™ã€‚ç”¨æˆ·å¯ä»¥å‘ç½‘ç«™æäº¤æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¤„ç†æ•°æ®ï¼Œå¹¶é€šè¿‡ç”µå­é‚®ä»¶æ¥æ”¶å¤„ç†ç»“æœã€‚æ•°æ®å­˜å‚¨åœ¨è¿è¡ŒäºAmazon EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šçš„MySQLæ•°æ®åº“ä¸­ã€‚æ•°æ®åº“è¿è¡Œåœ¨å…·æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªç§æœ‰å­ç½‘çš„VPCä¸­ã€‚ç½‘ç«™è¿è¡Œåœ¨Apache Tomcatä¸Šï¼Œä½äºä¸åŒVPCçš„å•ä¸ªEC2å®ä¾‹ä¸­ï¼Œè¯¥VPCæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå…¬æœ‰å­ç½‘ã€‚æ•°æ®åº“å’Œç½‘ç«™VPCä¹‹é—´æœ‰å•ä¸ªVPC Peeringè¿æ¥ã€‚ç”±äºé«˜æµé‡ï¼Œç½‘ç«™åœ¨ä¸Šä¸ªæœˆé­å—äº†å‡ æ¬¡ä¸­æ–­ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”é‡‡å–å“ªäº›æªæ–½æ¥æé«˜åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºçš„å¯é æ€§ï¼Ÿï¼ˆé€‰æ‹©ä¸‰é¡¹ï¼‰
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å°†TomcatæœåŠ¡å™¨æ”¾ç½®åœ¨Auto Scalingç»„ä¸­ï¼Œåœ¨Application Load Balanceråé¢é…ç½®å¤šä¸ªEC2å®ä¾‹ B. é…ç½®é¢å¤–çš„VPC Peeringè¿æ¥ C. å°†MySQLæ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»åˆ°Amazon Auroraï¼Œé…ç½®ä¸€ä¸ªAuroraå‰¯æœ¬ D. åœ¨æ•°æ®åº“VPCä¸­é…ç½®ä¸¤ä¸ªNATç½‘å…³ E. å°†TomcatæœåŠ¡å™¨ç§»åŠ¨åˆ°æ•°æ®åº“VPC F. åœ¨ç½‘ç«™VPCçš„ä¸åŒå¯ç”¨åŒºä¸­åˆ›å»ºé¢å¤–çš„å…¬æœ‰å­ç½‘
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³ç½‘ç«™å› é«˜æµé‡å¯¼è‡´çš„å¯é æ€§é—®é¢˜ï¼Œæé«˜ç³»ç»Ÿæ•´ä½“å¯ç”¨æ€§
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Bé€‰é¡¹é¢å¤–çš„VPC Peeringè¿æ¥ä¸èƒ½è§£å†³å¯é æ€§é—®é¢˜ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹NATç½‘å…³ä¸»è¦ç”¨äºå‡ºç«™è¿æ¥ï¼Œä¸ç›´æ¥æé«˜åº”ç”¨å¯é æ€§ï¼›Eé€‰é¡¹ç§»åŠ¨æœåŠ¡å™¨ä½ç½®ä¸èƒ½è§£å†³é«˜æµé‡é—®é¢˜
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è¯†åˆ«å•ç‚¹æ•…éšœï¼Œå®ç°æ°´å¹³æ‰©å±•ï¼Œå¢åŠ å†—ä½™æ€§ï¼Œæé«˜ç³»ç»Ÿæ•´ä½“å¯ç”¨æ€§
Question #438
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A retail company is operating its ecommerce application on AWS. The application runs on Amazon EC2 instances behind an Application Load Balancer (ALB). The company uses an Amazon RDS DB instance as the database backend. Amazon CloudFront is configured with one origin that points to the ALB. Static content is cached. Amazon Route 53 is used to host all public zones. After an update of the application, the ALB occasionally returns a 502 status code (Bad Gateway) error. The root cause is malformed HTTP headers that are returned to the ALB. The webpage returns successfully when a solutions architect reloads the webpage immediately after the error occurs. While the company is working on the problem, the solutions architect needs to provide a custom error page instead of the standard ALB error page to visitors. Which combination of steps will meet this requirement with the LEAST amount of operational overhead? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: S3CloudFrontRoute53EC2LambdaCloudWatch+1 more
Knowledge Areas: æ•…éšœæ’é™¤é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§
Scenarios: æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢CloudFronté”™è¯¯å¤„ç†é™æ€ç½‘ç«™æ‰˜ç®¡è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–
A.
Create an Amazon S3 bucket. Configure the S3 bucket to host a static webpage. Upload the custom error pages to Amazon S3.
B.
Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm to invoke an AWS Lambda function if the ALB health check response Target.FailedHealthChecks is greater than 0. Configure the Lambda function to modify the forwarding rule at the ALB to point to a publicly accessible web server.
C.
Modify the existing Amazon Route 53 records by adding health checks. Configure a fallback target if the health check fails. Modify DNS records to point to a publicly accessible webpage.
D.
Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm to invoke an AWS Lambda function if the ALB health check response Elb.InternalError is greater than 0. Configure the Lambda function to modify the forwarding rule at the ALB to point to a publicly accessible web server.
E.
Add a custom error response by configuring a CloudFront custom error page. Modify DNS records to point to a publicly accessible web page.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶é›¶å”®å…¬å¸åœ¨AWSä¸Šè¿è¥å…¶ç”µå•†åº”ç”¨ã€‚åº”ç”¨è¿è¡Œåœ¨Application Load Balancer (ALB)åçš„Amazon EC2å®ä¾‹ä¸Šã€‚å…¬å¸ä½¿ç”¨Amazon RDS DBå®ä¾‹ä½œä¸ºæ•°æ®åº“åç«¯ã€‚Amazon CloudFronté…ç½®äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæŒ‡å‘ALBçš„æºç«™ã€‚é™æ€å†…å®¹è¢«ç¼“å­˜ã€‚Amazon Route 53ç”¨äºæ‰˜ç®¡æ‰€æœ‰å…¬å…±åŒºåŸŸã€‚åº”ç”¨æ›´æ–°åï¼ŒALBå¶å°”è¿”å›502çŠ¶æ€ç (Bad Gateway)é”™è¯¯ã€‚æ ¹æœ¬åŸå› æ˜¯è¿”å›ç»™ALBçš„HTTPå¤´æ ¼å¼é”™è¯¯ã€‚å½“è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåœ¨é”™è¯¯å‘ç”Ÿåç«‹å³é‡æ–°åŠ è½½ç½‘é¡µæ—¶ï¼Œç½‘é¡µè¿”å›æˆåŠŸã€‚åœ¨å…¬å¸è§£å†³é—®é¢˜æœŸé—´ï¼Œè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆéœ€è¦ä¸ºè®¿å®¢æä¾›è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯æ ‡å‡†çš„ALBé”™è¯¯é¡µé¢ã€‚å“ªç§æ­¥éª¤ç»„åˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æ»¡è¶³æ­¤è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ(é€‰æ‹©ä¸¤ä¸ª)
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºAmazon S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶ï¼Œé…ç½®S3å­˜å‚¨æ¡¶æ‰˜ç®¡é™æ€ç½‘é¡µï¼Œä¸Šä¼ è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢åˆ°Amazon S3 B. åˆ›å»ºAmazon CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦ï¼Œå½“ALBå¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥å“åº”Target.FailedHealthCheckså¤§äº0æ—¶è°ƒç”¨AWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°ï¼Œé…ç½®Lambdaå‡½æ•°ä¿®æ”¹ALBè½¬å‘è§„åˆ™æŒ‡å‘å¯å…¬å¼€è®¿é—®çš„WebæœåŠ¡å™¨ C. ä¿®æ”¹ç°æœ‰Amazon Route 53è®°å½•æ·»åŠ å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥ï¼Œé…ç½®å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥å¤±è´¥æ—¶çš„å›é€€ç›®æ ‡ï¼Œä¿®æ”¹DNSè®°å½•æŒ‡å‘å¯å…¬å¼€è®¿é—®çš„ç½‘é¡µ D. åˆ›å»ºAmazon CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦ï¼Œå½“ALBå¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥å“åº”Elb.InternalErrorå¤§äº0æ—¶è°ƒç”¨AWS Lambdaå‡½æ•°ï¼Œé…ç½®Lambdaå‡½æ•°ä¿®æ”¹ALBè½¬å‘è§„åˆ™æŒ‡å‘å¯å…¬å¼€è®¿é—®çš„WebæœåŠ¡å™¨ E. é€šè¿‡é…ç½®CloudFrontè‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢æ·»åŠ è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯å“åº”ï¼Œä¿®æ”¹DNSè®°å½•æŒ‡å‘å¯å…¬å¼€è®¿é—®çš„ç½‘é¡µ
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
åœ¨ALBè¿”å›502é”™è¯¯æ—¶ä¸ºç”¨æˆ·æä¾›è‡ªå®šä¹‰é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶æœ€å°åŒ–è¿ç»´å¼€é”€
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Bå’ŒDæ¶‰åŠå¤æ‚çš„CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦å’ŒLambdaå‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¿ç»´å¼€é”€å¤§ï¼›Cä½¿ç”¨Route53å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥ä½†æ— æ³•å¤„ç†é—´æ­‡æ€§çš„502é”™è¯¯ï¼Œä¸”è¿ç»´å¤æ‚åº¦é«˜ã€‚
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–ï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿæœ‰æ•ˆå¤„ç†é—´æ­‡æ€§502é”™è¯¯ï¼Œæä¾›ç”¨æˆ·å‹å¥½çš„é”™è¯¯é¡µé¢ä½“éªŒ
Question #439
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company wants to migrate an Amazon Aurora MySQL DB cluster from an existing AWS account to a new AWS account in the same AWS Region. Both accounts are members of the same organization in AWS Organizations. The company must minimize database service interruption before the company performs DNS cutover to the new database. Which migration strategy will meet this requirement? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: RDSSystems-Manager
Knowledge Areas: æ•°æ®åº“æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤
Scenarios: å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†æ•°æ®å¤‡ä»½
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»å¿«ç…§å…±äº«è·¨è´¦æˆ·è¿ç§»æœåŠ¡ä¸­æ–­æœ€å°åŒ–
A.
Take a snapshot of the existing Aurora database. Share the snapshot with the new AWS account. Create an Aurora DB cluster in the new account from the snapshot.
B.
Create an Aurora DB cluster in the new AWS account. Use AWS Database Migration Service (AWS DMS) to migrate data between the two Aurora DB clusters.
C.
Use AWS Backup to share an Aurora database backup from the existing AWS account to the new AWS account. Create an Aurora DB cluster in the new AWS account from the snapshot.
D.
Create an Aurora DB cluster in the new AWS account. Use AWS Application Migration Service to migrate data between the two Aurora DB clusters. https://www.examtopics.com/exams/amazon/aws-certified-solutions-architect-professional-sap-c02/custom-view/ 223/269 2024/7/9 18:19 AWS Certified Solutions Architect - Professional SAP-C02 Exam - Free Exam Q&As, Page 1 | ExamTopics
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸å¸Œæœ›å°†Amazon Aurora MySQLæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ä»ç°æœ‰AWSè´¦æˆ·è¿ç§»åˆ°åŒä¸€AWSåŒºåŸŸå†…çš„æ–°AWSè´¦æˆ·ã€‚ä¸¤ä¸ªè´¦æˆ·éƒ½æ˜¯AWS Organizationsä¸­åŒä¸€ç»„ç»‡çš„æˆå‘˜ã€‚å…¬å¸å¿…é¡»åœ¨æ‰§è¡ŒDNSåˆ‡æ¢åˆ°æ–°æ•°æ®åº“ä¹‹å‰æœ€å°åŒ–æ•°æ®åº“æœåŠ¡ä¸­æ–­ã€‚å“ªç§è¿ç§»ç­–ç•¥èƒ½æ»¡è¶³æ­¤è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿï¼ˆé€‰æ‹©ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼‰
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å¯¹ç°æœ‰Auroraæ•°æ®åº“åˆ›å»ºå¿«ç…§ï¼Œä¸æ–°AWSè´¦æˆ·å…±äº«å¿«ç…§ï¼Œåœ¨æ–°è´¦æˆ·ä¸­ä»å¿«ç…§åˆ›å»ºAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ B. åœ¨æ–°AWSè´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨AWS DMSåœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ä¹‹é—´è¿ç§»æ•°æ® C. ä½¿ç”¨AWS Backupå°†Auroraæ•°æ®åº“å¤‡ä»½ä»ç°æœ‰AWSè´¦æˆ·å…±äº«åˆ°æ–°AWSè´¦æˆ·ï¼Œåœ¨æ–°è´¦æˆ·ä¸­ä»å¿«ç…§åˆ›å»ºAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ D. åœ¨æ–°AWSè´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨AWS Application Migration Serviceåœ¨ä¸¤ä¸ªAuroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤ä¹‹é—´è¿ç§»æ•°æ®
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
åœ¨æœ€å°åŒ–æœåŠ¡ä¸­æ–­çš„å‰æä¸‹å°†Auroraæ•°æ®åº“é›†ç¾¤è·¨è´¦æˆ·è¿ç§»
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Cé€‰é¡¹AWS Backupä¸æ”¯æŒè·¨è´¦æˆ·Auroraå¤‡ä»½å…±äº«ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹Application Migration Serviceä¸é€‚ç”¨äºæ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æ”¯æŒè·¨è´¦æˆ·æ“ä½œã€æœ€å°åŒ–æœåŠ¡ä¸­æ–­ã€é€‚ç”¨äºAuroraæ•°æ®åº“è¿ç§»çš„æœåŠ¡é€‰æ‹©
Question #440
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A software as a service (SaaS) company provides a media software solution to customers. The solution is hosted on 50 VPCs across various AWS Regions and AWS accounts. One of the VPCs is designated as a management VPC. The compute resources in the VPCs work independently. The company has developed a new feature that requires all 50 VPCs to be able to communicate with each other. The new feature also requires one-way access from each customer's VPC to the company's management VPC. The management VPC hosts a compute resource that validates licenses for the media software solution. The number of VPCs that the company will use to host the solution will continue to increase as the solution grows. Which combination of steps will provide the required VPC connectivity with the LEAST operational overhead? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: VPCTransit-GatewayPrivateLinkSite-to-Site-VPNNLB
Knowledge Areas: ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§
Scenarios: å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥æ€§è¿ç»´å¼€é”€å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§å•å‘è®¿é—®æ§åˆ¶
A.
Create a transit gateway. Attach all the company's VPCs and relevant subnets to the transit gateway.
B.
Create VPC peering connections between all the company's VPCs.
C.
Create a Network Load Balancer (NLB) that points to the compute resource for license validation. Create an AWS PrivateLink endpoint service that is available to each customer's VPC. Associate the endpoint service with the NLB.
D.
Create a VPN appliance in each customer's VPC. Connect the company's management VPC to each customer's VPC by using AWS Site-to-Site VPN.
E.
Create a VPC peering connection between the company's management VPC and each customer's VPC.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶SaaSå…¬å¸ä¸ºå®¢æˆ·æä¾›åª’ä½“è½¯ä»¶è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚è¯¥è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ‰˜ç®¡åœ¨è·¨å¤šä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸå’Œè´¦æˆ·çš„50ä¸ªVPCä¸Šã€‚å…¶ä¸­ä¸€ä¸ªVPCè¢«æŒ‡å®šä¸ºç®¡ç†VPCã€‚å„VPCä¸­çš„è®¡ç®—èµ„æºç‹¬ç«‹å·¥ä½œã€‚å…¬å¸å¼€å‘äº†ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œè¦æ±‚æ‰€æœ‰50ä¸ªVPCèƒ½å¤Ÿç›¸äº’é€šä¿¡ã€‚æ–°åŠŸèƒ½è¿˜éœ€è¦ä»æ¯ä¸ªå®¢æˆ·VPCåˆ°å…¬å¸ç®¡ç†VPCçš„å•å‘è®¿é—®ã€‚ç®¡ç†VPCæ‰˜ç®¡éªŒè¯åª’ä½“è½¯ä»¶è®¸å¯è¯çš„è®¡ç®—èµ„æºã€‚éšç€è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆå¢é•¿ï¼Œå…¬å¸ä½¿ç”¨çš„VPCæ•°é‡å°†ç»§ç»­å¢åŠ ã€‚å“ªç§æ­¥éª¤ç»„åˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€å°‘è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æä¾›æ‰€éœ€çš„VPCè¿æ¥ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åˆ›å»ºTransit Gatewayï¼Œå°†æ‰€æœ‰å…¬å¸VPCå’Œç›¸å…³å­ç½‘è¿æ¥åˆ°Transit Gateway B. åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰å…¬å¸VPCä¹‹é—´åˆ›å»ºVPC Peeringè¿æ¥ C. åˆ›å»ºæŒ‡å‘è®¸å¯è¯éªŒè¯è®¡ç®—èµ„æºçš„NLBï¼Œåˆ›å»ºå¯ä¾›æ¯ä¸ªå®¢æˆ·VPCä½¿ç”¨çš„PrivateLinkç»ˆç«¯èŠ‚ç‚¹æœåŠ¡ï¼Œå°†ç»ˆç«¯èŠ‚ç‚¹æœåŠ¡ä¸NLBå…³è” D. åœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå®¢æˆ·VPCä¸­åˆ›å»ºVPNè®¾å¤‡ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Site-to-Site VPNå°†å…¬å¸ç®¡ç†VPCè¿æ¥åˆ°æ¯ä¸ªå®¢æˆ·VPC E. åœ¨å…¬å¸ç®¡ç†VPCå’Œæ¯ä¸ªå®¢æˆ·VPCä¹‹é—´åˆ›å»ºVPC Peeringè¿æ¥
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
å®ç°50ä¸ªVPCé—´çš„å…¨ç½‘çŠ¶é€šä¿¡å’Œå®¢æˆ·VPCåˆ°ç®¡ç†VPCçš„å•å‘è®¿é—®ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶æœ€å°åŒ–è¿ç»´å¼€é”€
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Bé€‰é¡¹VPC Peeringåœ¨å¤§è§„æ¨¡åœºæ™¯ä¸‹ç®¡ç†å¤æ‚ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹VPNè®¾å¤‡å¢åŠ è¿ç»´è´Ÿæ‹…ï¼›Eé€‰é¡¹åªè§£å†³äº†éƒ¨åˆ†è¿æ¥éœ€æ±‚
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
å¯æ‰©å±•æ€§, è¿ç»´å¤æ‚åº¦, ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„çš„çµæ´»æ€§, è®¿é—®æ§åˆ¶ç²’åº¦
Question #441
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company has multiple lines of business (LOBs) that roll up to the parent company. The company has asked its solutions architect to develop a solution with the following requirements: â€¢ Produce a single AWS invoice for all of the AWS accounts used by its LOBs. â€¢ The costs for each LOB account should be broken out on the invoice. â€¢ Provide the ability to restrict services and features in the LOB accounts, as defined by the company's governance policy. â€¢ Each LOB account should be delegated full administrator permissions, regardless of the governance policy. Which combination of steps should the solutions architect take to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: AWS OrganizationsIAM
Knowledge Areas: æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–åˆè§„æ€§å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†
Scenarios: å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†æˆæœ¬åˆ†æ
Exam Domain: Domain4-è®¾è®¡æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: åˆå¹¶è´¦å•æœåŠ¡æ§åˆ¶ç­–ç•¥ç»„ç»‡ç®¡ç†æˆæœ¬åˆ†é…
A.
Use AWS Organizations to create an organization in the parent account for each LOB. Then invite each LOB account to the appropriate organization.
B.
Use AWS Organizations to create a single organization in the parent account. Then, invite each LOB's AWS account to join the organization.
C.
Implement service quotas to define the services and features that are permitted and apply the quotas to each LOB as appropriate.
D.
Create an SCP that allows only approved services and features, then apply the policy to the LOB accounts.
E.
Enable consolidated billing in the parent account's billing console and link the LOB accounts.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸æœ‰å¤šä¸ªä¸šåŠ¡çº¿(LOB)éš¶å±äºæ¯å…¬å¸ã€‚å…¬å¸è¦æ±‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå¼€å‘æ»¡è¶³ä»¥ä¸‹è¦æ±‚çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼šâ€¢ ä¸ºæ‰€æœ‰LOBä½¿ç”¨çš„AWSè´¦æˆ·ç”Ÿæˆå•ä¸€AWSè´¦å•ã€‚â€¢ æ¯ä¸ªLOBè´¦æˆ·çš„æˆæœ¬åº”åœ¨è´¦å•ä¸Šåˆ†åˆ«åˆ—å‡ºã€‚â€¢ æ ¹æ®å…¬å¸æ²»ç†ç­–ç•¥ï¼Œæä¾›é™åˆ¶LOBè´¦æˆ·ä¸­æœåŠ¡å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½çš„èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚â€¢ æ— è®ºæ²»ç†ç­–ç•¥å¦‚ä½•ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªLOBè´¦æˆ·éƒ½åº”è¢«å§”æ´¾å®Œæ•´çš„ç®¡ç†å‘˜æƒé™ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆåº”é‡‡å–å“ªäº›æ­¥éª¤ç»„åˆæ¥æ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ(é€‰æ‹©ä¸¤ä¸ª)
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. ä½¿ç”¨AWS Organizationsåœ¨æ¯è´¦æˆ·ä¸­ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªLOBåˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªç»„ç»‡ï¼Œç„¶åé‚€è¯·æ¯ä¸ªLOBè´¦æˆ·åŠ å…¥ç›¸åº”ç»„ç»‡ B. ä½¿ç”¨AWS Organizationsåœ¨æ¯è´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºå•ä¸€ç»„ç»‡ï¼Œç„¶åé‚€è¯·æ¯ä¸ªLOBçš„AWSè´¦æˆ·åŠ å…¥è¯¥ç»„ç»‡ C. å®æ–½æœåŠ¡é…é¢æ¥å®šä¹‰å…è®¸çš„æœåŠ¡å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¹¶å°†é…é¢é€‚å½“åº”ç”¨äºæ¯ä¸ªLOB D. åˆ›å»ºåªå…è®¸æ‰¹å‡†æœåŠ¡å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½çš„SCPï¼Œç„¶åå°†ç­–ç•¥åº”ç”¨äºLOBè´¦æˆ· E. åœ¨æ¯è´¦æˆ·çš„è´¦å•æ§åˆ¶å°ä¸­å¯ç”¨åˆå¹¶è´¦å•å¹¶é“¾æ¥LOBè´¦æˆ·
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
å®ç°å¤šLOBè´¦æˆ·çš„ç»Ÿä¸€è´¦å•ç®¡ç†å’ŒæœåŠ¡æ²»ç†æ§åˆ¶
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-æ¯ä¸ªLOBåˆ›å»ºå•ç‹¬ç»„ç»‡æ— æ³•å®ç°ç»Ÿä¸€è´¦å•ï¼›C-æœåŠ¡é…é¢ä¸æ˜¯æ²»ç†æ§åˆ¶çš„æœ€ä½³æ–¹å¼ï¼›E-åˆå¹¶è´¦å•å·²åŒ…å«åœ¨Organizationsä¸­ï¼Œæ— éœ€å•ç‹¬å¯ç”¨
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
éœ€è¦ç»Ÿä¸€è´¦å•ç®¡ç†ã€æˆæœ¬åˆ†ç¦»ã€æœåŠ¡æ²»ç†æ§åˆ¶å’Œä¿æŒç®¡ç†å‘˜æƒé™çš„å¹³è¡¡
Question #442
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A solutions architect has deployed a web application that serves users across two AWS Regions under a custom domain. The application uses Amazon Route 53 latency-based routing. The solutions architect has associated weighted record sets with a pair of web servers in separate Availability Zones for each Region. The solutions architect runs a disaster recovery scenario. When all the web servers in one Region are stopped, Route 53 does not automatically redirect users to the other Region. Which of the following are possible root causes of this issue? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: Route53
Knowledge Areas: é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤æ•…éšœæ’é™¤
Scenarios: è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: å»¶è¿Ÿè·¯ç”±åŠ æƒè·¯ç”±å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥åˆ«åè®°å½•ç›®æ ‡å¥åº·è¯„ä¼°
A.
The weight for the Region where the web servers were stopped is higher than the weight for the other Region.
B.
One of the web servers in the secondary Region did not pass its HTTP health check.
C.
Latency resource record sets cannot be used in combination with weighted resource record sets.
D.
The setting to evaluate target health is not turned on for the latency alias resource record set that is associated with the domain in the Region where the web servers were stopped.
E.
An HTTP health check has not been set up for one or more of the weighted resource record sets associated with the stopped web servers.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆéƒ¨ç½²äº†ä¸€ä¸ªè·¨ä¸¤ä¸ªAWSåŒºåŸŸä¸ºç”¨æˆ·æä¾›æœåŠ¡çš„Webåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºï¼Œä½¿ç”¨è‡ªå®šä¹‰åŸŸåã€‚åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä½¿ç”¨Amazon Route 53åŸºäºå»¶è¿Ÿçš„è·¯ç”±ã€‚æ¶æ„å¸ˆä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸåœ¨ä¸åŒå¯ç”¨åŒºä¸­çš„ä¸€å¯¹WebæœåŠ¡å™¨å…³è”äº†åŠ æƒè®°å½•é›†ã€‚åœ¨ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤åœºæ™¯æµ‹è¯•ä¸­ï¼Œå½“ä¸€ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸçš„æ‰€æœ‰WebæœåŠ¡å™¨åœæ­¢æ—¶ï¼ŒRoute 53æ²¡æœ‰è‡ªåŠ¨å°†ç”¨æˆ·é‡å®šå‘åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹å“ªäº›æ˜¯å¯èƒ½çš„æ ¹æœ¬åŸå› ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœæ­¢WebæœåŠ¡å™¨çš„åŒºåŸŸæƒé‡é«˜äºå¦ä¸€ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸçš„æƒé‡ B. è¾…åŠ©åŒºåŸŸä¸­çš„ä¸€å°WebæœåŠ¡å™¨æœªé€šè¿‡HTTPå¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥ C. å»¶è¿Ÿèµ„æºè®°å½•é›†ä¸èƒ½ä¸åŠ æƒèµ„æºè®°å½•é›†ç»“åˆä½¿ç”¨ D. ä¸åœæ­¢WebæœåŠ¡å™¨åŒºåŸŸå…³è”çš„å»¶è¿Ÿåˆ«åèµ„æºè®°å½•é›†æœªå¼€å¯è¯„ä¼°ç›®æ ‡å¥åº·è®¾ç½® E. æœªä¸ºä¸åœæ­¢æœåŠ¡å™¨å…³è”çš„ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ–å¤šä¸ªåŠ æƒèµ„æºè®°å½•é›†è®¾ç½®HTTPå¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³Route53åœ¨ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤åœºæ™¯ä¸­æœªèƒ½è‡ªåŠ¨æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»çš„é—®é¢˜
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-æƒé‡ä¸å½±å“å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥æœºåˆ¶ï¼›B-å•å°æœåŠ¡å™¨æ•…éšœä¸ä¼šå½±å“æ•´ä¸ªåŒºåŸŸï¼›C-å»¶è¿Ÿè·¯ç”±å’ŒåŠ æƒè·¯ç”±å¯ä»¥ç»„åˆä½¿ç”¨
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
ç†è§£Route53å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥æœºåˆ¶å’Œåˆ«åè®°å½•çš„ç›®æ ‡å¥åº·è¯„ä¼°åŠŸèƒ½
Question #443
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A flood monitoring agency has deployed more than 10,000 water-level monitoring sensors. Sensors send continuous data updates, and each update is less than 1 MB in size. The agency has a fleet of on-premises application servers. These servers receive updates from the sensors, convert the raw data into a human readable format, and write the results to an on-premises relational database server. Data analysts then use simple SQL queries to monitor the data. The agency wants to increase overall application availability and reduce the effort that is required to perform maintenance tasks. These maintenance tasks, which include updates and patches to the application servers, cause downtime. While an application server is down, data is lost from sensors because the remaining servers cannot handle the entire workload. The agency wants a solution that optimizes operational overhead and costs. A solutions architect recommends the use of AWS IoT Core to collect the sensor data. What else should the solutions architect recommend to meet these requirements?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: LambdaS3RDS
Knowledge Areas: é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„è®¾è®¡
Scenarios: è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘è‡ªåŠ¨æ‰©å±•
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: IoTæ•°æ®æµå¤„ç†æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨æ¶æ„æ•°æ®æ ¼å¼è½¬æ¢æµå¼æ•°æ®å¤„ç†
A.
Send the sensor data to Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. Use an AWS Lambda function to read the Kinesis Data Firehose data, convert it to .csv format, and insert it into an Amazon Aurora MySQL DB instance. Instruct the data analysts to query the data directly from the DB instance.
B.
Send the sensor data to Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. Use an AWS Lambda function to read the Kinesis Data Firehose data, convert it to Apache Parquet format, and save it to an Amazon S3 bucket. Instruct the data analysts to query the data by using Amazon Athena.
C.
Send the sensor data to an Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flink (previously known as Amazon Kinesis Data Analytics) application to convert the data to .csv format and store it in an Amazon S3 bucket. Import the data into an Amazon Aurora MySQL DB instance. Instruct the data analysts to query the data directly from the DB instance.
D.
Send the sensor data to an Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flink (previously known as Amazon Kinesis Data Analytics) application to convert the data to Apache Parquet format and store it in an Amazon S3 bucket. Instruct the data analysts to query the data by using Amazon Athena.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€ä¸ªæ´ªæ°´ç›‘æµ‹æœºæ„éƒ¨ç½²äº†è¶…è¿‡10,000ä¸ªæ°´ä½ç›‘æµ‹ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨ã€‚ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨å‘é€è¿ç»­æ•°æ®æ›´æ–°ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡æ›´æ–°å°äº1MBã€‚è¯¥æœºæ„æœ‰ä¸€ç»„æœ¬åœ°åº”ç”¨æœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œæ¥æ”¶ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ›´æ–°ï¼Œå°†åŸå§‹æ•°æ®è½¬æ¢ä¸ºäººç±»å¯è¯»æ ¼å¼ï¼Œå¹¶å†™å…¥æœ¬åœ°å…³ç³»æ•°æ®åº“ã€‚æ•°æ®åˆ†æå¸ˆä½¿ç”¨ç®€å•SQLæŸ¥è¯¢ç›‘æ§æ•°æ®ã€‚æœºæ„å¸Œæœ›æé«˜æ•´ä½“åº”ç”¨å¯ç”¨æ€§ï¼Œå‡å°‘ç»´æŠ¤å·¥ä½œé‡ã€‚ç»´æŠ¤ä»»åŠ¡åŒ…æ‹¬åº”ç”¨æœåŠ¡å™¨æ›´æ–°å’Œè¡¥ä¸ï¼Œä¼šå¯¼è‡´åœæœºã€‚å½“åº”ç”¨æœåŠ¡å™¨åœæœºæ—¶ï¼Œå‰©ä½™æœåŠ¡å™¨æ— æ³•å¤„ç†å…¨éƒ¨å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®ä¸¢å¤±ã€‚æœºæ„éœ€è¦ä¼˜åŒ–è¿è¥å¼€é”€å’Œæˆæœ¬çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆå»ºè®®ä½¿ç”¨AWS IoT Coreæ”¶é›†ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®ã€‚è¿˜åº”è¯¥æ¨èä»€ä¹ˆæ¥æ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å°†ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®å‘é€åˆ°Amazon Kinesis Data Firehoseï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Lambdaå‡½æ•°è¯»å–æ•°æ®ï¼Œè½¬æ¢ä¸ºcsvæ ¼å¼ï¼Œæ’å…¥Aurora MySQLå®ä¾‹ï¼Œåˆ†æå¸ˆç›´æ¥æŸ¥è¯¢æ•°æ®åº“ B. å°†ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®å‘é€åˆ°Amazon Kinesis Data Firehoseï¼Œä½¿ç”¨Lambdaå‡½æ•°è¯»å–æ•°æ®ï¼Œè½¬æ¢ä¸ºParquetæ ¼å¼ï¼Œä¿å­˜åˆ°S3ï¼Œåˆ†æå¸ˆä½¿ç”¨AthenaæŸ¥è¯¢æ•°æ® C. å°†ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®å‘é€åˆ°Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flinkåº”ç”¨ï¼Œè½¬æ¢ä¸ºcsvæ ¼å¼å­˜å‚¨åˆ°S3ï¼Œå¯¼å…¥Aurora MySQLï¼Œåˆ†æå¸ˆç›´æ¥æŸ¥è¯¢æ•°æ®åº“ D. å°†ä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®å‘é€åˆ°Amazon Managed Service for Apache Flinkåº”ç”¨ï¼Œè½¬æ¢ä¸ºParquetæ ¼å¼å­˜å‚¨åˆ°S3ï¼Œåˆ†æå¸ˆä½¿ç”¨AthenaæŸ¥è¯¢æ•°æ®
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä¸ºIoTä¼ æ„Ÿå™¨æ•°æ®å¤„ç†è®¾è®¡é«˜å¯ç”¨ã€ä½ç»´æŠ¤æˆæœ¬çš„äº‘ç«¯è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆ
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-csvæ ¼å¼å­˜å‚¨æ•ˆç‡ä½ï¼ŒAuroraéœ€è¦ç»´æŠ¤ï¼›Cå’ŒD-Apache Flinkè¿‡äºå¤æ‚ï¼Œå¢åŠ è¿è¥å¼€é”€ï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆç®€åŒ–ç»´æŠ¤çš„è¦æ±‚

Question #444
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜é«˜çº§
A public retail web application uses an Application Load Balancer (ALB) in front of Amazon EC2 instances running across multiple Availability Zones (AZs) in a Region backed by an Amazon RDS MySQL Multi-AZ deployment. Target group health checks are configured to use HTTP and pointed at the product catalog page. Auto Scaling is configured to maintain the web fleet size based on the ALB health check. Recently, the application experienced an outage. Auto Scaling continuously replaced the instances during the outage. A subsequent investigation determined that the web server metrics were within the normal range, but the database tier was experiencing high load, resulting in severely elevated query response times. Which of the following changes together would remediate these issues while improving monitoring capabilities for the availability and functionality of the entire application stack for future growth? (Choose two.)
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EC2RDSAuto-ScalingCloudWatchRoute53ElastiCache
Knowledge Areas: æ•…éšœæ’é™¤æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŒ–è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§
Scenarios: è´Ÿè½½å‡è¡¡è‡ªåŠ¨æ‰©å±•
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥åˆ†ç¦»æ•°æ®åº“ç¼“å­˜ç›‘æ§å‘Šè­¦è¯»å†™åˆ†ç¦»
A.
Configure read replicas for Amazon RDS MySQL and use the single reader endpoint in the web application to reduce the load on the backend database tier.
B.
Configure the target group health check to point at a simple HTML page instead of a product catalog page and the Amazon Route 53 health check against the product page to evaluate full application functionality. Configure Amazon CloudWatch alarms to notify administrators when the site fails.
C.
Configure the target group health check to use a TCP check of the Amazon EC2 web server and the Amazon Route 53 health check against the product page to evaluate full application functionality. Configure Amazon CloudWatch alarms to notify administrators when the site fails.
D.
Configure an Amazon CloudWatch alarm for Amazon RDS with an action to recover a high-load, impaired RDS instance in the database tier.
E.
Configure an Amazon ElastiCache cluster and place it between the web application and RDS MySQL instances to reduce the load on the backend database tier.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€ä¸ªå…¬å…±é›¶å”®Webåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä½¿ç”¨Application Load Balancer (ALB)ï¼Œå‰ç«¯æ˜¯è¿è¡Œåœ¨æŸä¸ªåŒºåŸŸå¤šä¸ªå¯ç”¨åŒºçš„Amazon EC2å®ä¾‹ï¼Œåç«¯æ˜¯Amazon RDS MySQL Multi-AZéƒ¨ç½²ã€‚ç›®æ ‡ç»„å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥é…ç½®ä¸ºä½¿ç”¨HTTPå¹¶æŒ‡å‘äº§å“ç›®å½•é¡µé¢ã€‚Auto Scalingé…ç½®ä¸ºåŸºäºALBå¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥ç»´æŠ¤WebæœåŠ¡å™¨é›†ç¾¤å¤§å°ã€‚æœ€è¿‘åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºç»å†äº†ä¸€æ¬¡æ•…éšœï¼ŒAuto Scalingåœ¨æ•…éšœæœŸé—´æŒç»­æ›¿æ¢å®ä¾‹ã€‚åç»­è°ƒæŸ¥ç¡®å®šWebæœåŠ¡å™¨æŒ‡æ ‡åœ¨æ­£å¸¸èŒƒå›´å†…ï¼Œä½†æ•°æ®åº“å±‚æ­£åœ¨ç»å†é«˜è´Ÿè½½ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æŸ¥è¯¢å“åº”æ—¶é—´ä¸¥é‡å‡é«˜ã€‚ä»¥ä¸‹å“ªäº›æ›´æ”¹èƒ½å¤Ÿä¿®å¤è¿™äº›é—®é¢˜ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶æ”¹å–„æ•´ä¸ªåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå †æ ˆçš„å¯ç”¨æ€§å’ŒåŠŸèƒ½ç›‘æ§èƒ½åŠ›ä»¥æ”¯æŒæœªæ¥å¢é•¿ï¼Ÿï¼ˆé€‰æ‹©ä¸¤ä¸ªï¼‰
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. ä¸ºAmazon RDS MySQLé…ç½®åªè¯»å‰¯æœ¬ï¼Œåœ¨Webåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºä¸­ä½¿ç”¨å•ä¸€è¯»å–å™¨ç«¯ç‚¹æ¥å‡å°‘åç«¯æ•°æ®åº“å±‚çš„è´Ÿè½½ B. é…ç½®ç›®æ ‡ç»„å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥æŒ‡å‘ç®€å•HTMLé¡µé¢è€Œä¸æ˜¯äº§å“ç›®å½•é¡µé¢ï¼Œé…ç½®Amazon Route 53å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥é’ˆå¯¹äº§å“é¡µé¢ä»¥è¯„ä¼°å®Œæ•´åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºåŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œé…ç½®Amazon CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦åœ¨ç«™ç‚¹æ•…éšœæ—¶é€šçŸ¥ç®¡ç†å‘˜ C. é…ç½®ç›®æ ‡ç»„å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥ä½¿ç”¨Amazon EC2 WebæœåŠ¡å™¨çš„TCPæ£€æŸ¥ï¼Œé…ç½®Amazon Route 53å¥åº·æ£€æŸ¥é’ˆå¯¹äº§å“é¡µé¢ä»¥è¯„ä¼°å®Œæ•´åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºåŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œé…ç½®Amazon CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦åœ¨ç«™ç‚¹æ•…éšœæ—¶é€šçŸ¥ç®¡ç†å‘˜ D. ä¸ºAmazon RDSé…ç½®Amazon CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦ï¼Œå½“æ•°æ®åº“å±‚å‡ºç°é«˜è´Ÿè½½å—æŸRDSå®ä¾‹æ—¶æ‰§è¡Œæ¢å¤æ“ä½œ E. é…ç½®Amazon ElastiCacheé›†ç¾¤å¹¶å°†å…¶æ”¾ç½®åœ¨Webåº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºå’ŒRDS MySQLå®ä¾‹ä¹‹é—´ä»¥å‡å°‘åç«¯æ•°æ®åº“å±‚çš„è´Ÿè½½
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è§£å†³æ•°æ®åº“é«˜è´Ÿè½½å¯¼è‡´çš„çº§è”æ•…éšœé—®é¢˜å¹¶æ”¹å–„ç›‘æ§èƒ½åŠ›
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aé€‰é¡¹åªè¯»å‰¯æœ¬ä¸»è¦ç”¨äºè¯»å†™åˆ†ç¦»ä½†é¢˜ç›®æœªæ˜ç¡®è¯»å¤šå†™å°‘åœºæ™¯ï¼›Cé€‰é¡¹TCPæ£€æŸ¥æ— æ³•æ£€æµ‹WebæœåŠ¡å™¨åº”ç”¨å±‚é—®é¢˜ï¼›Dé€‰é¡¹RDS Multi-AZå·²æœ‰è‡ªåŠ¨æ•…éšœè½¬ç§»ï¼ŒCloudWatchæ— æ³•ç›´æ¥æ¢å¤é«˜è´Ÿè½½å®ä¾‹
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†

Question #445
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company has an on-premises data center and is using Kubernetes to develop a new solution on AWS. The company uses Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) clusters for its development and test environments. The EKS control plane and data plane for production workloads must reside on premises. The company needs an AWS managed solution for Kubernetes management. Which solution will meet these requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EKS
Knowledge Areas: å®¹å™¨åŒ–æ··åˆäº‘æ¶æ„è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§
Scenarios: æ··åˆäº‘æ¶æ„è¿ç§»ä¸Šäº‘
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æœ¬åœ°é›†ç¾¤é…ç½®æ‰©å±•é›†ç¾¤é…ç½®EKS AnywhereAWS Outpostsæ§åˆ¶å¹³é¢æœ¬åœ°åŒ–
A.
Install an AWS Outposts server in the on-premises data center. Deploy Amazon EKS by using a local cluster configuration on the Outposts server for the production workloads.
B.
Install Amazon EKS Anywhere on the company's hardware in the on-premises data center. Deploy the production workloads on an EKS Anywhere cluster.
C.
Install an AWS Outposts server in the on-premises data center. Deploy Amazon EKS by using an extended cluster configuration on the Outposts server for the production workloads.
D.
Install an AWS Outposts server in the on-premises data center. Install Amazon EKS Anywhere on the Outposts server. Deploy the production workloads on an EKS Anywhere cluster.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸æ‹¥æœ‰æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒï¼Œæ­£åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨Kubernetesåœ¨AWSä¸Šå¼€å‘æ–°è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚å…¬å¸åœ¨å¼€å‘å’Œæµ‹è¯•ç¯å¢ƒä¸­ä½¿ç”¨Amazon EKSé›†ç¾¤ã€‚ç”Ÿäº§å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½çš„EKSæ§åˆ¶å¹³é¢å’Œæ•°æ®å¹³é¢å¿…é¡»é©»ç•™åœ¨æœ¬åœ°ã€‚å…¬å¸éœ€è¦AWSæ‰˜ç®¡çš„Kubernetesç®¡ç†è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆã€‚å“ªç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æ»¡è¶³è¿™äº›è¦æ±‚ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. åœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒå®‰è£…AWS OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œåœ¨OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šä½¿ç”¨æœ¬åœ°é›†ç¾¤é…ç½®éƒ¨ç½²Amazon EKSç”¨äºç”Ÿäº§å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½ B. åœ¨å…¬å¸æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒçš„ç¡¬ä»¶ä¸Šå®‰è£…Amazon EKS Anywhereï¼Œåœ¨EKS Anywhereé›†ç¾¤ä¸Šéƒ¨ç½²ç”Ÿäº§å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½ C. åœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒå®‰è£…AWS OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œåœ¨OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šä½¿ç”¨æ‰©å±•é›†ç¾¤é…ç½®éƒ¨ç½²Amazon EKSç”¨äºç”Ÿäº§å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½ D. åœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ•°æ®ä¸­å¿ƒå®‰è£…AWS OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ï¼Œåœ¨OutpostsæœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šå®‰è£…Amazon EKS Anywhereï¼Œåœ¨EKS Anywhereé›†ç¾¤ä¸Šéƒ¨ç½²ç”Ÿäº§å·¥ä½œè´Ÿè½½
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
åœ¨æœ¬åœ°éƒ¨ç½²EKSæ§åˆ¶å¹³é¢å’Œæ•°æ®å¹³é¢ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶è·å¾—AWSæ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡çš„ä¾¿åˆ©æ€§å’Œæœ€å°‘è¿ç»´å¼€é”€
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Bç¼ºå°‘AWSæ‰˜ç®¡åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½æ”¯æŒï¼›Cçš„æ‰©å±•é›†ç¾¤é…ç½®æ§åˆ¶å¹³é¢ä»åœ¨AWSäº‘ç«¯ï¼›Då¢åŠ äº†ä¸å¿…è¦çš„å¤æ‚æ€§å’Œæˆæœ¬
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
æ§åˆ¶å¹³é¢æœ¬åœ°åŒ–è¦æ±‚, AWSæ‰˜ç®¡æœåŠ¡éœ€æ±‚, è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–
Question #446
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company uses AWS Organizations to manage its development environment. Each development team at the company has its own AWS account. Each account has a single VPC and CIDR blocks that do not overlap. The company has an Amazon Aurora DB cluster in a shared services account. All the development teams need to work with live data from the DB cluster. Which solution will provide the required connectivity to the DB cluster with the LEAST operational overhead?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: VPCRDSRoute53
Knowledge Areas: ç½‘ç»œæ¶æ„æ•°æ®åº“å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†
Scenarios: å¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†ç½‘ç»œéš”ç¦»
Exam Domain: Domain1-è®¾è®¡å¼¹æ€§æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: è·¨è´¦æˆ·èµ„æºå…±äº«ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–
A.
Create an AWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM) resource share for the DB cluster. Share the DB cluster with all the development accounts.
B.
Create a transit gateway in the shared services account. Create an AWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM) resource share for the transit gateway. Share the transit gateway with all the development accounts. Instruct the developers to accept the resource share. Configure networking.
C.
Create an Application Load Balancer (ALB) that points to the IP address of the DB cluster. Create an AWS PrivateLink endpoint service that uses the ALB. Add permissions to allow each development account to connect to the endpoint service.
D.
Create an AWS Site-to-Site VPN connection in the shared services account. Configure networking. Use AWS Marketplace VPN software in each development account to connect to the Site-to-Site VPN connection.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸ä½¿ç”¨AWS Organizationsç®¡ç†å…¶å¼€å‘ç¯å¢ƒã€‚å…¬å¸çš„æ¯ä¸ªå¼€å‘å›¢é˜Ÿéƒ½æœ‰è‡ªå·±çš„AWSè´¦æˆ·ã€‚æ¯ä¸ªè´¦æˆ·éƒ½æœ‰å•ä¸ªVPCå’Œä¸é‡å çš„CIDRå—ã€‚å…¬å¸åœ¨å…±äº«æœåŠ¡è´¦æˆ·ä¸­æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªAmazon Aurora DBé›†ç¾¤ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰å¼€å‘å›¢é˜Ÿéƒ½éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨DBé›†ç¾¤ä¸­çš„å®æ—¶æ•°æ®ã€‚å“ªç§è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆèƒ½ä»¥æœ€å°‘çš„è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æä¾›åˆ°DBé›†ç¾¤çš„æ‰€éœ€è¿æ¥ï¼Ÿ
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. ä¸ºDBé›†ç¾¤åˆ›å»ºAWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM)èµ„æºå…±äº«ï¼Œä¸æ‰€æœ‰å¼€å‘è´¦æˆ·å…±äº«DBé›†ç¾¤ B. åœ¨å…±äº«æœåŠ¡è´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºtransit gatewayï¼Œåˆ›å»ºAWS RAMèµ„æºå…±äº«å¹¶ä¸æ‰€æœ‰å¼€å‘è´¦æˆ·å…±äº«ï¼ŒæŒ‡å¯¼å¼€å‘äººå‘˜æ¥å—èµ„æºå…±äº«å¹¶é…ç½®ç½‘ç»œ C. åˆ›å»ºæŒ‡å‘DBé›†ç¾¤IPåœ°å€çš„Application Load Balancer (ALB)ï¼Œåˆ›å»ºä½¿ç”¨ALBçš„AWS PrivateLinkç«¯ç‚¹æœåŠ¡ï¼Œæ·»åŠ æƒé™å…è®¸æ¯ä¸ªå¼€å‘è´¦æˆ·è¿æ¥åˆ°ç«¯ç‚¹æœåŠ¡ D. åœ¨å…±äº«æœåŠ¡è´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºAWS Site-to-Site VPNè¿æ¥ï¼Œé…ç½®ç½‘ç»œï¼Œåœ¨æ¯ä¸ªå¼€å‘è´¦æˆ·ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨AWS Marketplace VPNè½¯ä»¶è¿æ¥åˆ°Site-to-Site VPN
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
ä¸ºå¤šä¸ªå¼€å‘è´¦æˆ·æä¾›è®¿é—®å…±äº«Auroraæ•°æ®åº“çš„è¿æ¥æ–¹æ¡ˆï¼Œè¦æ±‚è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
A-Auroraä¸èƒ½ç›´æ¥é€šè¿‡RAMå…±äº«ï¼›C-ALBä¸é€‚ç”¨äºæ•°æ®åº“è¿æ¥ä¸”é…ç½®å¤æ‚ï¼›D-VPNæ–¹æ¡ˆè¿ç»´å¼€é”€å¤§ä¸”ä¸é€‚åˆå†…éƒ¨è´¦æˆ·äº’è¿
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
è¿ç»´å¼€é”€æœ€å°åŒ–, è·¨è´¦æˆ·ç½‘ç»œè¿æ¥çš„æ ‡å‡†å®è·µ, æœåŠ¡å…¼å®¹æ€§
Question #447
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company used AWS CloudFormation to create all new infrastructure in its AWS member accounts. The resources rarely change and are properly sized for the expected load. The monthly AWS bill is consistent. Occasionally, a developer creates a new resource for testing and forgets to remove the resource when the test is complete. Most of these tests last a few days before the resources are no longer needed. The company wants to automate the process of finding unused resources. A solutions architect needs to design a solution that determines whether the cost in the AWS bill is increasing. The solution must help identify resources that cause an increase in cost and must automatically notify the company's operations team. Which solution will meet these requirements?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: CloudWatchCloudFormation
Knowledge Areas: æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–è¿ç»´ç›‘æ§
Scenarios: æˆæœ¬åˆ†æå¤šè´¦æˆ·ç®¡ç†
Exam Domain: Domain4-è®¾è®¡æˆæœ¬ä¼˜åŒ–æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: æˆæœ¬å¼‚å¸¸æ£€æµ‹è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–ç›‘æ§æˆæœ¬å‘Šè­¦èµ„æºç®¡ç†
A.
Turn on billing alerts. Use AWS Cost Explorer to determine the costs for the past month. Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm for total estimated charges. Specify a cost threshold that is higher than the costs that Cost Explorer determined. Add a notification to alert the operations team if the alarm threshold is breached.
B.
Turn on billing alerts. Use AWS Cost Explorer to determine the average monthly costs for the past 3 months. Create an Amazon CloudWatch alarm for total estimated charges. Specify a cost threshold that is higher than the costs that Cost Explorer determined. Add a notification to alert the operations team if the alarm threshold is breached.
C.
Use AWS Cost Anomaly Detection to create a cost monitor that has a monitor type of Linked account. Create a subscription to send daily AWS cost summaries to the operations team. Specify a threshold for cost variance.
D.
Use AWS Cost Anomaly Detection to create a cost monitor that has a monitor type of AWS services. Create a subscription to send daily AWS cost summaries to the operations team. Specify a threshold for cost variance.
ğŸ“– é¢˜ç›®ç¿»è¯‘
ä¸€å®¶å…¬å¸ä½¿ç”¨AWS CloudFormationåœ¨å…¶AWSæˆå‘˜è´¦æˆ·ä¸­åˆ›å»ºæ‰€æœ‰æ–°åŸºç¡€è®¾æ–½ã€‚èµ„æºå¾ˆå°‘å˜æ›´ä¸”é’ˆå¯¹é¢„æœŸè´Ÿè½½è¿›è¡Œäº†é€‚å½“è°ƒæ•´ã€‚æœˆåº¦AWSè´¦å•ä¿æŒä¸€è‡´ã€‚å¶å°”ï¼Œå¼€å‘äººå‘˜ä¼šåˆ›å»ºæ–°èµ„æºè¿›è¡Œæµ‹è¯•ï¼Œä½†åœ¨æµ‹è¯•å®Œæˆåå¿˜è®°åˆ é™¤èµ„æºã€‚å¤§å¤šæ•°æµ‹è¯•æŒç»­å‡ å¤©åèµ„æºå°±ä¸å†éœ€è¦ã€‚å…¬å¸å¸Œæœ›è‡ªåŠ¨åŒ–æŸ¥æ‰¾æœªä½¿ç”¨èµ„æºçš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¶æ„å¸ˆéœ€è¦è®¾è®¡ä¸€ä¸ªè§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆæ¥ç¡®å®šAWSè´¦å•ä¸­çš„æˆæœ¬æ˜¯å¦åœ¨å¢åŠ ã€‚è¯¥è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆå¿…é¡»å¸®åŠ©è¯†åˆ«å¯¼è‡´æˆæœ¬å¢åŠ çš„èµ„æºï¼Œå¹¶è‡ªåŠ¨é€šçŸ¥å…¬å¸çš„è¿ç»´å›¢é˜Ÿã€‚
ğŸ”¤ é€‰é¡¹ç¿»è¯‘
A. å¼€å¯è´¦å•å‘Šè­¦ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨AWS Cost Explorerç¡®å®šè¿‡å»ä¸€ä¸ªæœˆçš„æˆæœ¬ã€‚ä¸ºæ€»é¢„ä¼°è´¹ç”¨åˆ›å»ºCloudWatchå‘Šè­¦ã€‚æŒ‡å®šé«˜äºCost Explorerç¡®å®šæˆæœ¬çš„é˜ˆå€¼ã€‚æ·»åŠ é€šçŸ¥ä»¥åœ¨è¶…è¿‡å‘Šè­¦é˜ˆå€¼æ—¶æé†’è¿ç»´å›¢é˜Ÿã€‚ B. å¼€å¯è´¦å•å‘Šè­¦ã€‚ä½¿ç”¨AWS Cost Explorerç¡®å®šè¿‡å»3ä¸ªæœˆçš„å¹³å‡æœˆåº¦æˆæœ¬ã€‚ä¸ºæ€»é¢„ä¼°è´¹ç”¨åˆ›å»ºCloudWatchå‘Šè­¦ã€‚æŒ‡å®šé«˜äºCost Explorerç¡®å®šæˆæœ¬çš„é˜ˆå€¼ã€‚æ·»åŠ é€šçŸ¥ä»¥åœ¨è¶…è¿‡å‘Šè­¦é˜ˆå€¼æ—¶æé†’è¿ç»´å›¢é˜Ÿã€‚ C. ä½¿ç”¨AWS Cost Anomaly Detectionåˆ›å»ºç›‘æ§ç±»å‹ä¸ºå…³è”è´¦æˆ·çš„æˆæœ¬ç›‘æ§å™¨ã€‚åˆ›å»ºè®¢é˜…å‘è¿ç»´å›¢é˜Ÿå‘é€æ¯æ—¥AWSæˆæœ¬æ‘˜è¦ã€‚æŒ‡å®šæˆæœ¬å·®å¼‚é˜ˆå€¼ã€‚ D. ä½¿ç”¨AWS Cost Anomaly Detectionåˆ›å»ºç›‘æ§ç±»å‹ä¸ºAWSæœåŠ¡çš„æˆæœ¬ç›‘æ§å™¨ã€‚åˆ›å»ºè®¢é˜…å‘è¿ç»´å›¢é˜Ÿå‘é€æ¯æ—¥AWSæˆæœ¬æ‘˜è¦ã€‚æŒ‡å®šæˆæœ¬å·®å¼‚é˜ˆå€¼ã€‚
ğŸ¯ æ ¸å¿ƒè¦æ±‚
è‡ªåŠ¨æ£€æµ‹æˆæœ¬å¢åŠ å¹¶è¯†åˆ«å¯¼è‡´æˆæœ¬å¢åŠ çš„èµ„æº
âŒ é”™è¯¯é€‰é¡¹åˆ†æ
Aå’ŒBä½¿ç”¨å›ºå®šé˜ˆå€¼çš„CloudWatchå‘Šè­¦æ— æ³•è‡ªåŠ¨é€‚åº”æ­£å¸¸çš„æˆæœ¬æ³¢åŠ¨ï¼›Cä½¿ç”¨å…³è”è´¦æˆ·ç›‘æ§ç±»å‹æ— æ³•è¯†åˆ«å…·ä½“çš„èµ„æºç±»å‹
âš–ï¸ å†³ç­–æ ‡å‡†
éœ€è¦è‡ªåŠ¨æ£€æµ‹å¼‚å¸¸æˆæœ¬å˜åŒ–å¹¶èƒ½è¯†åˆ«å…·ä½“å¯¼è‡´æˆæœ¬å¢åŠ çš„èµ„æºç±»å‹
Question #448
âšª å•é€‰é¢˜ä¸­çº§
A company is deploying a new web-based application and needs a storage solution for the Linux application servers. The company wants to create a single location for updates to application data for all instances. The active dataset will be up to 100 GB in size. A solutions architect has determined that peak operations will occur for 3 hours daily and will require a total of 225 MiBps of read throughput. The solutions architect must design a Multi-AZ solution that makes a copy of the data available in another AWS Region for disaster recovery (DR). The DR copy has an RPO of less than 1 hour. Which solution will meet these requirements?
ğŸ·ï¸ Knowledge Tags
AWS Services: EFSFSxEBSDataSyncAuto-Scaling
Knowledge Areas: å­˜å‚¨ç®¡ç†ç¾éš¾æ¢å¤é«˜å¯ç”¨æ€§
Scenarios: è·¨åŒºåŸŸéƒ¨ç½²æ•°æ®å¤‡ä»½
Exam Domain: Domain2-è®¾è®¡é«˜æ€§èƒ½æ¶æ„
Key Concepts: å…±äº«å­˜å‚¨ååé‡æ€§èƒ½Multi-AZè·¨åŒºåŸŸå¤åˆ¶RPO
A.
Deploy a new Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) Multi-AZ file system. Configure the file system for 75 MiBps of provisioned throughput. Implement replication to a file system in the DR Region.
B.
Deploy a new Amazon FSx for Lustre file system. Configure Bursting Throughput mode for the file system. Use AWS Backup to back up the file system to the DR Region.
C.
